{
  "article_text": [
    "a classical way of presenting certain closed orientable @xmath0-manifolds is by taking cyclic covers of @xmath1 branched along knots .",
    "this article deals with the question of understanding in how many ways a given manifold can be presented as the total space of a cyclic branched cover of some knot .",
    "given a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 , these different presentations are in one - to - one correspondence with conjugacy classes of the corresponding groups of deck transformations .",
    "these are finite cyclic groups generated by periodic diffeomorphisms with connected and non - empty fixed - point set , and orbit space homeomorphic to the @xmath0-sphere .",
    "we call such diffeomorphisms _ hyperelliptic rotations_.    for example , the @xmath0-sphere is the @xmath3-fold cyclic branched cover of the trivial knot for any integer @xmath4 . on the other hand , due to the orbifold theorem , it is known that for a closed @xmath0-manifold which is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 , the order of a hyperelliptic rotation is bounded by a constant depending on the manifold , see @xcite .",
    "so when @xmath2 is not the @xmath0-sphere @xmath1 one may ask whether there is a universal upper bound for the number of distinct conjugacy classes of groups of deck transformations associated to cyclic branched covers .",
    "we show that this is indeed the case if the manifold is hyperbolic . for the general case of irreducible manifolds",
    "we obtain a universal bound only for the groups of deck transformations that have odd prime order .",
    "establishing such a universal upper bound for hyperbolic @xmath0-manifolds boils down to bounding the number of conjugacy classes of cyclic groups of isometries generated by hyperelliptic rotations inside the finite group of isometries of the manifold . since any finite group acts on some hyperbolic @xmath0-manifold @xcite",
    ", @xcite we have to consider any finite group action on a @xmath0-manifold .",
    "the proof , however , only uses that the manifold is not @xmath1 , so our main result is the following    [ th : main4 ] let @xmath2 be a closed orientable connected @xmath0-manifold which is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath5 be a finite group of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of @xmath2 .",
    "then @xmath5 contains at most six conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of order not a power of @xmath6 .    thanks to previous work of one of the authors ( @xcite ) and of m. reni ( @xcite ) on hyperelliptic rotations of orders a power of @xmath6 ( see section  [ sec : generalization ] , theorem  [ th : powers of two ] ) , we deduce :    [ cor:4bis ] let @xmath2 be a closed orientable connected @xmath0-manifold which is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath5 be a finite group of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of @xmath2 .",
    "then @xmath5 contains at most fifteen conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation .",
    "moreover , the set of orders of such subgroups has cardinality at most nine .",
    "the above corollary applies in particular to the orientation preserving group of isometries @xmath7 of a closed hyperbolic @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 which is finite .",
    "since any finite group of orientation preserving diffemorphisms acting on @xmath2 is conjugate to a subgroup of @xmath7 , the following is a direct consequence of corollary  [ cor:4bis ]    [ cor : hyperbolic ] a closed orientable connected hyperbolic @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 is a cyclic cover of @xmath1 along a knot for at most fifteen distinct knots .",
    "the possible branching orders are at most nine .    from corollary  [ cor:4bis ]",
    "it is also possible to derive a characterisation of the @xmath0-sphere :    [ cor : char1 ] a closed , connected , orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 is homeomorphic to @xmath1 if and only if there is a finite goup @xmath5 of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of @xmath2 such that @xmath5 contains sixteen conjugacy classes of subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations .",
    "one interesting aspect of the proof of theorem  [ th : main4 ] is the substantial use of finite group theory and the classification of finite simple groups . in particular",
    ", it relies on previous works on finite groups acting on @xmath0-manifolds by two of the authors in @xcite and @xcite .",
    "a crucial point is to control the rank of the @xmath8-sylow subgroup of a finite group acting on a @xmath0-manifold .",
    "more precisely , the proof of theorem  [ th : main4 ] splits into various cases , according to the structures of the normalisers of the sylow @xmath8-subgroups containing an element of order @xmath8 that is a power of a hyperelliptic rotation , where @xmath8 is an odd prime number .",
    "this structure is reflected in the symmetry group of the branching knot in the quotient @xmath1 of the manifold by the action of the hyperelliptic rotation , see proposition  [ prop : symmetries and normalizer ] in section  [ sec : rotations ] .",
    "note that , although the proof of theorem  [ th : main4 ] uses the classification of finite simple groups , it is enough to know that there is only a finite number of sporadic simple groups ( that is , groups that are not alternating or of lie type ) to conclude on the existence of a uniform bound on the number of conjugacy classes . since",
    ", as we have already observed , every finite group acts on some closed orientable @xmath0-manifold ( see also section  [ sec : nonfree ] ) there is no way to avoid relying on the classification of finite simple groups to prove the above results .",
    "if we only consider @xmath0-manifolds that are @xmath9-homology spheres though , the proof of theorem  [ th : main4 ] ( with the very same bounds ) only relies on the gorenstein - harada classification of simple groups with sectional @xmath6-rank @xmath10 , @xcite , see corollary  [ cor : z2spheres ] .",
    "indeed , the homological condition provides control on the size of the sylow @xmath6-subgroups of finite groups that can act on such manifolds . for other topological conditions that impose constraints on the finite groups that can act on a manifold",
    "see @xcite .",
    "it follows from the proof of theorem  [ th : main4 ] that the existence of at least four distinct conjugacy classes of hyperelliptic rotations of orders not powers of @xmath6 in a finite group @xmath5 of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed @xmath0-manifold imposes constraints on the structure of @xmath5 .",
    "a description of the structure of @xmath5 , which is somehow technical , is given in proposition  [ prop : structure ] .    _",
    "irreducible @xmath0-manifolds _    theorem  [ th : main4 ] has several geometric consequences , notably on the different ways a given manifold can appear as the total space of a cyclic cover of @xmath1 branched along a knot , without requiring that the manifold is hyperbolic .",
    "[ th : knots ] let @xmath2 be a closed orientable connected irreducible @xmath0-manifold .",
    "then there are at most six inequivalent knots in @xmath1 having @xmath2 as cyclic branched cover of odd prime order    theorem  [ th : knots ] follows from theorem  [ th : main4 ] and the existence of an equivariant geometric decomposition for a closed irreducible @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 with finite effective and non free group action , according to the orbifold theorem , see for example @xcite , and also @xcite , @xcite , @xcite .",
    "[ rem : montesinos ] * a ) * note that one can not hope to extend the result of theorem  [ th : knots ] to arbitrary prime orders . indeed ,",
    "although a universal bound exists on the number of knots that can be double covered by a given hyperbolic manifold by work of reni @xcite , no such bound exists in general .",
    "in fact , given any integer @xmath3 there are infinitely many closed orientable seifert fibred @xmath0-manifolds with at least @xmath3 conjugacy classes of hyperelliptic rotations of order @xmath6 , see remark  [ rem : brieskorn ] in section  [ sec : seifert ] . as in the case of seifert fibred manifolds , other types of toroidal manifolds , that is manifolds with a non trivial jsj - decomposition , can also admit arbitrarily many conjugacy classes of hyperelliptic rotations of order @xmath6 . as a consequence",
    "the finiteness result of theorem  [ th : knots ] does not hold for @xmath6-fold branched covers in general .    * b ) *",
    "also , one can not extend the result of theorem  [ th : knots ] to arbitrary orders that are not powers of @xmath6 , like in theorem  [ th : main4 ] : in section  [ sec : seifert ] we give examples of closed , irreducible , orientable seifert fibered @xmath0-manifolds with an arbitrarily large number of conjugacy classes of cyclic groups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd , but not prime , orders , see proposition [ prop : circle bundles ] .",
    "our examples are not rational homology spheres , while the primeness assumption for the orders of the hyperelliptic rotations forces the manifold @xmath2 to be a rational homology sphere , see remark  [ rem : coverings ] in section  [ sec : rotations ] .",
    "_ arbitrary @xmath0-manifolds _    using the decomposition of a closed orientable connected @xmath0-manifold as a connected sum of prime manifolds , we deduce from theorem  [ th : knots ] an upper bound on the number of odd primes that can occur as orders of hyperelliptic rotations of arbitrary closed @xmath0-manifolds .",
    "remark that for any @xmath11 and every odd prime @xmath8 there are non prime @xmath0-manifolds that are the @xmath8-fold cyclic covers of at least @xmath12 non equivalent knots , so that theorem  [ th : knots ] does not generalise to arbitrary manifolds .",
    "[ th : main ] let @xmath2 be a closed ( orientable ) connected @xmath0-manifold which is not homeomorphic to the @xmath0-sphere @xmath1 .",
    "then @xmath2 is a @xmath8-fold cyclic cover of @xmath1 branched along a knot for at most six distinct odd prime numbers @xmath8 .",
    "in @xcite three of the authors showed that the upper bound is @xmath0 for the number of odd prime orders of hyperelliptic rotations acting on an integral homology sphere . in that case",
    ", the proof relies heavily on the restrictions on finite groups acting on integral homology @xmath0-spheres .",
    "such restrictions can not exist in general since , as we observed at the beginning , every finite group does act on some closed orientable @xmath0-manifold .",
    "even if we only consider cyclic branched covers of knots of prime orders , which are rational homology spheres , no restriction can be obtained a priori , for every finite group acts on some rational homology sphere @xcite : the actions constructed in @xcite are free , but the same proof shows that for each finite group @xmath5 it is also possible to construct a faithful and non free action of @xmath5 on some rational homology sphere ( see the section  [ sec : nonfree ] for more details on this ) .    at this point",
    "we do not know if the bound of corollary  [ th : main ] is sharp .",
    "so far , only exemples of manifolds that are @xmath8-fold cyclic covers of @xmath1 branched along a knot for three distinct odd primes @xmath8 and for @xmath13 are known .",
    "exemples are provided , for instance , by brieskorn spheres of type @xmath14 , where @xmath8 , @xmath15 , and @xmath16 are three pairwise different odd primes : @xmath14 is the @xmath8-fold ( resp .",
    "@xmath15-fold and @xmath16-fold ) cyclic cover of @xmath1 branched along the torus knot @xmath17 ( resp . @xmath18 and @xmath19 ) as well as the double branched cover of a montesinos knot .",
    "examples of hyperbolic manifolds that are @xmath8-fold cyclic covers of @xmath1 branched along a knot for three distinct odd primes @xmath8 can also be exhibited @xcite .",
    "corollary  [ th : main ] gives yet another characterisation of the @xmath0-sphere , @xmath1 :    [ cor : primeorders ] a closed orientable connected @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 is homeomorphic to @xmath1 if and only if @xmath2 is a @xmath8-cyclic cover of @xmath1 branched along a knot for at least seven distinct odd prime numbers .",
    "the paper is organised as follows . in section  [ sec : rotations ] we define what _",
    "( hyperelliptic ) rotations _ are and determine different types of algebraic properties and constraints that they must satisfy . in section",
    "[ sec : solvable ] , we give a proof of theorem  [ th : main4 ] under the extra hypothesis that the group @xmath5 is solvable . in this case",
    "it is not difficult to show that , up to conjugacy , all hyperelliptic rotations must commute .",
    "the central part of the paper is consacrated to the proof of a weaker version of theorem  [ th : main4 ] , in which hyperelliptic rotations are assumed to have odd prime order , namely :    [ th : main3 ] let @xmath2 be a closed orientable connected @xmath0-manifold which is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath5 be a finite group of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of @xmath2 .",
    "then @xmath5 contains at most six conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order .    in section  [ sec :",
    "finite action ] we recall some standard definitions in finite group theory and provide several preliminary results that will be used in the following . the actual proof of theorem  [ th : main3 ] is split into two cases according to different properties of the hyperelliptic rotations contained in @xmath5 and their associated quotient knots . in section  [ sec : nonselfsym ] we assume that at least one of the knots is not _ self - symmetric _ ( see section  [ sec : rotations ] for a definition and the translation of this property into algebraic terms ) , while in section  [ sec : thm3 ] we assume that none is . in section  [ sec : generalization ] we explain how the proof of theorem  [ th : main4 ] can be reduced to that of theorem  [ th : main3 ] .",
    "the reduction of the proof relies basically on the fact that the sylow @xmath8-subgroup containing a non - trivial power of a hyperelliptic rotation has the same structure as that of a sylow @xmath8-subgroup containing a hyperelliptic rotation of order @xmath8 .",
    "in particular , all the key ingredients and essential difficulties are already encountered in the proof of theorem  [ th : main3 ] . in this section",
    "we also give the proof of corollary  [ cor:4bis ] .",
    "in section  [ sec : reducible ] we show that theorems  [ th : main4 ] and [ th : main3 ] are trivially fulfilled if the manifold is reducible , for no interesting finite group action exists on such manifolds .",
    "section [ sec : knots ] is devoted to the proof of theorem  [ th : knots ] and corollary  [ th : main ] .",
    "more precisely , in section  [ sec : seifert ] we show that theorem  [ th : knots ] holds for seifert fibred manifolds , while in section  [ sec : reduction ] theorem  [ th : knots ] is deduced from theorem  [ th : main3 ] for the remaining irreducible @xmath0-manifolds , that is hyperbolic @xmath0-manifolds , and @xmath0-manifolds admitting a non trivial jsj - decomposition .",
    "finally , in section  [ sec : nonfree ] , we see why every finite group acts non freely on some rational homology sphere .",
    "in this section we shall introduce certain special periodic diffeomorphisms and establish some of their properties .",
    "note that all through the paper , unless otherwise stated , _",
    "@xmath0-manifold _ will mean orientable , connected , closed @xmath0-manifold .",
    "also , all finite group actions by diffeomorphisms will be faithful and orientation preserving .",
    "let @xmath20 be a finite order diffeomorphism of a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 .",
    "we shall say that @xmath21 is a _ rotation _ if it preserves the orientation of @xmath2 , @xmath22 is non - empty and connected , and @xmath23 for all non trivial powers @xmath24 of @xmath21 .",
    "@xmath22 will be referred to as the _ axis of the rotation_. note that if @xmath21 is a periodic diffeomorphism of prime order , then @xmath21 is a rotation if and only if @xmath25 .",
    "we shall say that a rotation @xmath21 is _ hyperelliptic _ if the space of orbits @xmath26 of its action is @xmath1 .",
    "[ rem : coverings ] assume that @xmath21 is a hyperelliptic rotation acting on a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 then :    1 .",
    "the natural projection from @xmath2 to the space of orbits @xmath26 of @xmath21 is a cyclic cover of @xmath1 branched along a knot @xmath27 .",
    "the converse is also true , that is any deck transformation generating the automorphism group of a cyclic covering of @xmath1 branched along a knot is a hyperelliptic rotation .",
    "if the order of @xmath21 is a prime @xmath8 , then @xmath2 is a @xmath28-homology sphere @xcite .",
    "we start with a somehow elementary remark which is however central to determine constraints on finite groups acting on @xmath0-manifolds .",
    "[ rem : normaliser ] let @xmath29 be a finite group of diffeomorphisms acting on a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 .",
    "one can choose a riemannian metric on @xmath2 which is invariant by @xmath5 and with respect to which @xmath5 acts by isometries .",
    "let now @xmath30 be a rotation .",
    "since the normaliser @xmath31 of @xmath21 in @xmath5 consists precisely of those diffeomorphisms that leave the circle @xmath22 invariant , we deduce that @xmath32 is a finite subgroup of @xmath33 , where the nontrivial element in @xmath34 acts by conjugation sending each element of @xmath35 to its inverse .",
    "note that the elements of @xmath31 are precisely those that rotate about @xmath22 , translate along @xmath22 , or invert the orientation of @xmath22 ; in the last case the elements have order @xmath6 and non empty fixed - point set meeting @xmath22 in two points .    note that if @xmath36 and @xmath21 is a hyperelliptic rotation of order @xmath37 , then its centraliser @xmath38 in @xmath5 satisfies @xmath39 , where @xmath40 is cyclic , possibly trivial .",
    "this follows easily from the positive solution to smith s conjecture which implies that any group of symmetries of a non - trivial knot @xmath41 ( that is , any finite group of orientation - preserving diffeomorphisms of @xmath1 acting on the pair @xmath42 ) is either cyclic or dihedral .",
    "[ def : rot - inv ] with the notation of the above remark , we shall call _ @xmath22-rotations _ the elements of @xmath31 that preserve the orientation of @xmath22 and _ @xmath22-inversions _ those that reverse it .",
    "[ lem : commuting powers suffice ] consider two rotations contained in a finite group of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 .    1 .   a non trivial power of the first rotation commutes with a non trivial power of the second , both of orders different from @xmath6 , if and only if the two rotations commute . 2 .",
    "assume @xmath36 .",
    "if the two rotations are hyperelliptic and their fixed - point sets coincide , then they generate the same cyclic group ( in particular they have the same order ) .    *",
    "part 1 * the sufficiency of the condition being obvious , we only need to prove the necessity .",
    "remark that we can assume that both rotations act as isometries for some fixed riemannian metric on the manifold . to fix ideas , denote by @xmath21 and @xmath43 the two rotations and by @xmath44 and @xmath45 respectively their non trivial powers .",
    "note that , by definition , @xmath46 and @xmath47 . since @xmath44 and @xmath45 commute , @xmath44 leaves invariant @xmath47 and thus normalises every rotation about @xmath48 .",
    "moreover @xmath44 and @xmath43 commute , for the order of @xmath44 is not @xmath6 ( see remark  [ rem : normaliser ] ) . in particular @xmath43 leaves @xmath46 invariant and normalises every rotation about @xmath22 . the conclusion follows .",
    "* part 2 * reasoning as in part 1 , one sees that the two rotations commute .",
    "assume , by contradiction , that the subgroups they generate are different . under this assumption , at least one of the two subgroups",
    "is not contained in the other . without loss of generality",
    "we can assume that @xmath49 .",
    "take the quotient of @xmath2 by the action of @xmath21 .",
    "the second rotation @xmath43 induces a non - trivial rotation of @xmath1 which leaves the quotient knot @xmath50 invariant .",
    "moreover , this induced rotation fixes pointwise the knot @xmath41 .",
    "the positive solution to smith s conjecture implies now that @xmath41 is the trivial knot and thus @xmath51 , against the hypothesis .",
    "let @xmath2 be a @xmath28-homology sphere , @xmath8 a prime number .",
    "if @xmath21 is a periodic diffeomorphism of order @xmath8 acting on @xmath2 then , according to smith s theory , either @xmath21 acts freely on @xmath2 or it is a rotation .",
    "a generalisation of this fact is the following result whose proof can be found in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* prop 4 , page 679 ) :    [ lem:2rot ] let @xmath52 act faithfully on a @xmath28-homology sphere .",
    "then either @xmath40 contains precisely two cyclic subgroups generated by rotations or @xmath13 and all three cyclic subgroups are generated by rotations .",
    "the previous remark and the above lemma have the following consequence :    [ pro : sylow ] assume that the odd prime @xmath8 is the order of a rotation @xmath45 inside a finite group of diffeomorphisms @xmath5 acting faithfully on and preserving the orientation of a @xmath28-homology sphere @xmath2 .",
    "the sylow @xmath8-subgroup @xmath53 of @xmath5 is either cyclic or of the form @xmath54 .",
    "up to conjugacy we can assume that @xmath55 . according to remark  [ rem : normaliser ]",
    ", the normaliser @xmath56 of @xmath57 in @xmath53 is either cyclic or of the form @xmath54 , for @xmath8 is odd .",
    "we want to show that @xmath58 . according to ( * ? ? ?",
    "* , page 88 ) , either @xmath58 or there exists @xmath59 .",
    "if @xmath60 is cyclic , then every element of @xmath61 must normalise the group generated by @xmath45 so that @xmath58 .",
    "we can thus assume that @xmath62 and consider its characteristic subgroup @xmath63 which contains @xmath45 .",
    "@xmath40 acts on @xmath2 which is a @xmath28-homology sphere hence , according to lemma  [ lem:2rot ] , @xmath40 contains precisely two cyclic subgroups generated by rotations ( one being generated by @xmath45 and the other , say , by @xmath64 ) .",
    "assume now , by contradiction , that @xmath65 .",
    "we can then choose @xmath66 as described above . since the order of @xmath66 is odd , @xmath66 can not exchange @xmath67 and @xmath68 , so @xmath66 must normalise the group generated by @xmath45 and a contradiction is reached , proving the proposition .",
    "[ pro : normsylow ] let @xmath69 be a finite group acting on a @xmath28-homology sphere @xmath2 .",
    "let @xmath70 be a rotation of odd prime order @xmath8 and @xmath71 be a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath5 containing @xmath45 .",
    "then @xmath72 contains @xmath73 with index at most @xmath6 and contains an abelian subgroup of rank at most @xmath6 with index at most @xmath74 .",
    "in particular @xmath72 is solvable .",
    "the sylow @xmath8-subgroup @xmath71 is described in proposition  [ pro : sylow ] and @xmath73 is described in remark  [ rem : normaliser ] : since @xmath71 is abelian we clearly have @xmath75 .",
    "the normaliser of @xmath57 in @xmath5 contains @xmath67-rotations and @xmath67-inversions , hence it is contained in @xmath72 . if each element in @xmath72 normalises @xmath57 ( in particular if @xmath71 is cyclic ) , we are done",
    ". otherwise @xmath71 has rank two and contains precisely two subgroups of order @xmath8 generated by a rotation ( the group generated by @xmath45 and another one ; see lemma  [ lem:2rot ] ) .",
    "each element contained in the complement @xmath76 exchanges by conjugation these two cyclic groups , so the index of @xmath77 in @xmath72 is two .",
    "the results of the previous subsection apply in particular to hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime order @xmath8 .",
    "indeed , in propositions  [ pro : sylow ] and [ pro : normsylow ] the condition that @xmath2 is a @xmath28-homology sphere can be replaced by the condition that @xmath45 is a hyperelliptic rotation of order @xmath8 , according to part 2 of remark  [ rem : coverings ] .",
    "better still , in what follows we will show that it suffices that @xmath45 is a power of odd prime order of a hyperelliptic rotation to reach the same conclusions .",
    "[ lem:2hyprot ] let @xmath8 be an odd prime and assume that @xmath52 acts faithfully by orientation preserving diffeomorphisms on a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 .",
    "assume , moreover , that @xmath40 contains a non - trivial power @xmath45 of a hyperelliptic rotation @xmath43 of @xmath2 .",
    "then @xmath40 contains at most two subgroups generated by elements with non - empty fixed - point sets .",
    "first of all , it is not restrictive to assume that @xmath2 is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 , otherwise we are done by lemma  [ lem:2rot ] .    we need",
    "to prove that , besides the cyclic group generated by the rotation @xmath45 , @xmath40 contains at most one other cyclic subgroup generated by an element @xmath44 so that @xmath78 .",
    "reasoning as in the proof of the first part of lemma  [ lem : commuting powers suffice ] , the elements of @xmath40 commute with @xmath43 and thus induce symmetries of the non trivial knot @xmath79 . also , since @xmath43 commutes with every subgoup of @xmath40 it leaves setwise invariant each fixed - point set of cyclic subgroups of @xmath40 .",
    "we observe now that if @xmath5 is a finite group acting by orientation preserving diffeomorphisms on a manifold and @xmath80 are two elements such that @xmath81 then @xmath82 is cyclic ; in particular if @xmath66 and @xmath83 have the same order they generate the same subgroup .",
    "this can be easily seen by considering a @xmath5-equivariant riemmanian structure on @xmath2 .    as a consequence",
    "different cyclic subgroups inside @xmath40 acting non freely must have different fixed - point sets . since @xmath84 maps to a rotation of @xmath1 this implies that at most one cyclic group other than @xmath85 has non - empty fixed - point set .",
    "the following proposition is just a restatement of propositions  [ pro : sylow ] and [ pro : normsylow ] in this setting and it is also proved in the very same way using the fact that by lemma  [ lem:2hyprot ] there are at most two cyclic subgroups of order @xmath8 having non - empty fixed - point set .    [ pro : hyperellipticnormsylow ]",
    "let @xmath69 be a finite group acting on a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 .",
    "let @xmath70 be an element of odd prime order @xmath8 which is a non - trivial power of a hyperelliptic rotation .",
    "let @xmath71 be a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath5 containing @xmath45 .",
    "then    * the sylow @xmath8-subgroup @xmath71 is either cyclic or the product of two cyclic groups , and * its normaliser @xmath72 contains @xmath73 with index at most @xmath6 , and contains an abelian subgroup of rank at most @xmath6 with index at most @xmath74 .",
    "in particular @xmath72 is solvable .",
    "this general observation will be useful in the future .",
    "[ rem : conjugate - rotations ] under the hypotheses of proposition  [ pro : normsylow ] or of proposition  [ pro : hyperellipticnormsylow ] , the normaliser of @xmath71 contains the normaliser of @xmath86 with index @xmath6 if and only if the two cyclic subgroups generated by the two rotations in @xmath71 are conjugate .",
    "this case happens if and only if @xmath72 contains elements of order a power of @xmath6 which do not act in the same way on all elements of order @xmath8 in @xmath71 .",
    "indeed , all elements in @xmath73 either commute with all elements of order @xmath8 or act dihedrally .",
    "on the other hand , any element @xmath44 in @xmath76 conjugates @xmath45 to a rotation @xmath87 generating a different cyclic group , so that ( up to perhaps taking a power of @xmath44 ) one has @xmath88 and @xmath89 , i.e. @xmath44 acts dihedrally on some elements of order @xmath8 while it commutes with others .",
    "a _ rotation of a knot _ @xmath41 in @xmath1 is a rotation @xmath21 of @xmath1 such that @xmath90 and @xmath91 .",
    "we shall say that @xmath21 is a _ full rotation _ if @xmath92 in @xmath93 is the trivial knot .",
    "[ rem : full iff hyperelliptic ] let @xmath21 and @xmath43 be two commuting rotations acting on some manifold @xmath2 whose orders are different from @xmath6 and whose axes are distinct .",
    "assume that @xmath21 is hyperelliptic .",
    "in this case @xmath43 induces a rotation @xmath94 of @xmath27 , for @xmath95 ( see remark  [ rem : normaliser ] ) .",
    "we have that @xmath43 is hyperelliptic if and only if @xmath94 is a full rotation .",
    "this can be seen by considering the quotient of @xmath2 by the action of the group generated by @xmath21 and @xmath43 .",
    "this quotient is @xmath1 and the projection onto it factors through @xmath96 , which can be seen as a cyclic cover of @xmath1 branched along @xmath97 . by the positive solution to the smith conjecture , @xmath96 is @xmath1 if and only if @xmath97 is the trivial knot .",
    "the following finiteness result about commuting rotations of a non trivial knot in @xmath1 is one of the main ingredients in the proof of theorem  [ th : main2 ] ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 2 ) , and ( * ? ? ? * theorem 2 ) for a stronger result where commutativity is not required ) .",
    "[ prop : commuting rotations ] let @xmath41 be a non - trivial knot in @xmath1 .",
    "then there are at most two non conjugate cyclic subgroups of @xmath98 generated by pairwise commuting full rotations .",
    "assume by contradiction that there are three non conjugate cyclic groups generated by commuting full rotations of @xmath41 , @xmath43 , @xmath21 and @xmath99 respectively .",
    "if two of them -say @xmath43 , @xmath21- have the same axis , then by hypothesis they can not have the same order .",
    "fix the one with smaller order -say @xmath21- : the quotient @xmath92 is the trivial knot , and @xmath43 induces a rotation of @xmath92 which is non trivial since @xmath43 commutes with @xmath21 and its order is distinct from that of @xmath21 .",
    "the axis @xmath100 of this induced symmetry is the image of @xmath22 in the quotient @xmath101 by the action of @xmath21 .",
    "in particular @xmath92 and @xmath100 form a hopf link and @xmath41 is the trivial knot : this follows from the equivariant dehn lemma , see @xcite .",
    "we can thus assume that the axes are pairwise disjoint .",
    "since the rotations commute , even if one of them has order @xmath6 , it can not act as a strong inversion on the axes of the other rotations .",
    "therefore we would have that the axis of @xmath99 , which is a trivial knot , admits two commuting rotations , @xmath43 and @xmath21 , with distinct axes , which is impossible : this follows , for instance , from the fact ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* thm 5.2 ) ) that one can find a fibration of the complement of the trivial knot which is equivariant with respect to the two symmetries .",
    "observe that the proof of the proposition shows that two commuting full rotations of a non trivial knot either generate the same cyclic group or have disjoint axes .",
    "[ rem : prime ] if a knot @xmath102 admits a full rotation , then it is a prime knot , see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 2 ) .",
    "let now @xmath69 be a finite group of diffeomorphisms acting on @xmath36 .",
    "assume that @xmath5 contains a hyperelliptic rotation @xmath43 admitting a non - trivial power @xmath45 of odd prime order @xmath8 .",
    "let @xmath41 be the non trivial knot @xmath103 .",
    "the proof of theorems  [ th : main3 ] and [ th : main4 ] will be divided into different cases according to the structure of the normalisers of the sylow @xmath8-subroups of @xmath5 containing ( non trivial powers of ) hyperelliptic rotations .    in what follows",
    "we will provide a dictionary translating between algebraic properties of the structure of the normaliser of @xmath57 in @xmath5 and of the sylow @xmath8-subgroup containing it , and the existence of special symmetries of @xmath41 .",
    "we need the following definition .",
    "a @xmath6-component link is called _ exchangeable _ if there exists an orientation - preserving diffeomorphism of @xmath1 which exchanges the two components of the link .",
    "let @xmath41 be a knot and @xmath21 a rotation of @xmath41 of order @xmath3 and with axis @xmath100 .",
    "consider the @xmath6-component link @xmath104 consisting of the images of the knot @xmath41 and of the axis @xmath100 in the quotient @xmath105 of the @xmath0-sphere by the action of @xmath21 .",
    "note that at least one component of this link ( i.e. @xmath106 ) is trivial .",
    "we call @xmath41 _ @xmath3-self - symmetric _ if @xmath104 is exchangeable . in this case",
    "@xmath21 is a full rotation of @xmath41 .",
    "-self - symmetric knot on the left , and its exchangeable quotient link on the right.,title=\"fig:\",height=151 ]    since the structure of the normaliser of @xmath57 and of its centraliser , only depend on the symmetries of @xmath41 that lift to @xmath5 , we introduce the following definitions :    [ def : relg ] let @xmath5 be a finite group of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed connected @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 .",
    "let @xmath43 be a hyperelliptic rotation contained in @xmath5 with quotient knot @xmath41 .",
    "we say that @xmath41 is _ strongly invertible with respect to @xmath5 _ if @xmath41 admits a strong inversion that lifts to @xmath5 .",
    "similarly we say that @xmath41 is _ self - symmetric with respect to @xmath5 _ if @xmath5 contains an element @xmath107 conjugate to @xmath43 such that the subgroup @xmath108 is abelian of rank @xmath6 , i.e. not cyclic .",
    "remark that in the latter case @xmath41 is @xmath3-self - symmetric , where @xmath3 is the order of @xmath43 .",
    "[ prop : symmetries and normalizer ] let @xmath41 , @xmath43 , @xmath45 , and @xmath5 be as above .    * the centraliser of @xmath57 in @xmath5 is contained with index @xmath6 in its normaliser if and only if @xmath41 is strongly invertible with respect to @xmath5 .",
    "* the normaliser of @xmath85 in @xmath5 is contained with index @xmath6 in the normaliser of @xmath109 in @xmath5 if and only if @xmath41 is self - symmetric with respect to @xmath5 .",
    "moreover , if @xmath2 is hyperbolic and @xmath110 , @xmath41 is strongly invertible if and only if it is strongly invertible with respect to @xmath5 , and it is self - symmetric with respect to @xmath5 if and only if it is @xmath3-self - symmetric , where @xmath3 is the order of the hyperelliptic rotation @xmath43 .",
    "the necessity of the two conditions follows readily from definition  [ def : relg ] , so we only need to prove their sufficiency .",
    "any element in the normaliser of @xmath85 leaves @xmath67 setwise invariant and so belongs to the normaliser of @xmath111 . as a consequence",
    "any element in the normaliser of @xmath57 induces a symmetry of @xmath41 .",
    "if the normaliser of @xmath57 is not abelian , it must contain @xmath67-inversions which induce strong inversions of the knot @xmath41 .",
    "this proves the first part of the proposition .    for the second part",
    ", we have already noticed that the centraliser of @xmath45 must contain a second cyclic subgroup generated by a rotation @xmath64 conjugate to @xmath45 . the element @xmath44 of @xmath5 conjugating @xmath45",
    "to @xmath64 must map @xmath67 to @xmath68 . as a consequence",
    ", @xmath44 conjugates @xmath43 to a hyperelliptic rotation @xmath107 such that @xmath112 , having @xmath64 as non trivial power .",
    "the first part of lemma  [ lem : commuting powers suffice ] tells us that @xmath43 and @xmath107 commute so that @xmath107 induces a full @xmath3-rotation of @xmath41 , where @xmath3 is the order of @xmath43 and @xmath107 . to see that @xmath41 is @xmath3-self - symmetric it suffices to remark that the element @xmath44 , which normalises @xmath113 , induces a symmetry of the quotient link since it exchanges @xmath48 and @xmath114 .",
    "when @xmath2 is hyperbolic , @xmath41 is a hyperbolic knot and it has a finite group of symmetries whose lift to @xmath2 is contained in @xmath115 .",
    "in this section we prove a stronger version of theorem [ th : main3 ] for a finite solvable subgroup of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold .",
    "this is a key result not only for the proof of theorem  [ th : main3 ] , but also to reduce the proof of theorem  [ th : main2 ] to the one of theorem  [ th : main3 ] .",
    "[ prop : commuting 2 ] let @xmath5 be a finite group acting on a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 and let @xmath116 be @xmath3 rotations of @xmath2 with odd prime orders .",
    "assume that , up to conjugacy , the @xmath117s are contained in a solvable subgroup of @xmath5 .",
    "then , up to conjugacy , the rotations @xmath117 commute .",
    "we can assume that @xmath5 itself is solvable .",
    "then , applying  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* thm 5.6 , page 104 ) , up to conjugacy all the rotations belong to the same subgroup of maximal odd order .",
    "in particular we may assume that @xmath5 itself has odd order .",
    "let @xmath21 be a rotation of prime order @xmath8 and let @xmath71 be a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath5 containing @xmath21 .",
    "remark  [ rem : normaliser ] implies that @xmath118 is abelian , for the order of @xmath5 is odd . in particular",
    ", @xmath71 is central in its normalizer and ( * ? ? ?",
    "* thm 2.10 , page 144 ) implies that @xmath5 is the semidirect product of a characteristic subgroup @xmath119 and @xmath71 .",
    "let @xmath43 be another rotation .",
    "if @xmath43 has order @xmath8 , then up to conjugacy , @xmath43 sits inside @xmath71 and thus it commutes with @xmath21 according to proposition  [ pro : sylow ] .",
    "so let us assume that @xmath43 has order a prime @xmath120 .",
    "then @xmath43 belongs to @xmath119 . since @xmath8 is coprime to the order of @xmath119",
    ", @xmath21 must normalise at least one sylow @xmath15-subgroup @xmath121 of @xmath119 . up to conjugacy",
    ", we may assume that @xmath43 is contained in @xmath121 .",
    "reasoning as above , we see that @xmath21 must normalise at least one of the @xmath5-conjugates of @xmath122 . by remark  [ rem : normaliser ] , this implies that , up to conjugacy , @xmath21 and @xmath43 commute .",
    "[ cor : commuting 2 ] let @xmath5 be a finite group acting on a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 and let @xmath123 be @xmath3 rotations of @xmath2 with orders that are not powers of @xmath6 .",
    "assume that , up to conjugacy , the @xmath124s are contained in a solvable subgroup of @xmath5 , then , up to conjugacy , the rotations @xmath124 commute .    for each @xmath125 let @xmath117 be a power of @xmath124 of odd prime order .",
    "apply proposition  [ prop : commuting 2 ] to the @xmath3 rotations @xmath117 , then the first part of lemma  [ lem : commuting powers suffice ] to reach the desired conclusion .",
    "[ th : solvable ] let @xmath5 be a finite solvable group acting on a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 which is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 . up to conjugacy , @xmath5 contains at most three cyclic subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of orders which are not powers of @xmath6 .",
    "moreover , either their orders are pairwise distinct or there are at most two such rotations .",
    "assume that there are @xmath3 such rotations . according to corollary  [ cor : commuting",
    "2 ] we can assume that all these @xmath3 rotations commute . by remark  [ rem : full iff hyperelliptic ]",
    ", we then have a non trivial knot ( for @xmath36 ) admitting @xmath126 commuting full rotations .",
    "it follows immediately from proposition  [ prop : commuting rotations ] that @xmath127 .",
    "note that , by the positive solution to smith s conjecture , a non trivial knot can not admit two distinct and commuting cyclic groups of symmetries of the same order .",
    "this proves the latter part of the theorem .",
    "the goal of this section is to prove some useful results about hyperelliptic rotations in a finite subgroup of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold .",
    "again , all finite groups will be assumed to act faithfully by orientation preserving diffeomorphisms on some closed , connected @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 .",
    "let @xmath69 be a finite group acting on a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 .",
    "we say that an odd prime number @xmath8 is _ hyperelliptic _ for @xmath5 if @xmath5 contains a hyperelliptic rotation of order @xmath8 .",
    "we remark once more that , if @xmath8 is hyperelliptic for @xmath5 , then the @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 is a @xmath28-homology @xmath0-sphere . moreover , if @xmath45 is a hyperelliptic rotation of order @xmath8 its normaliser and centraliser are determined in remark  [ rem : normaliser ] .",
    "[ rem : centralizer - factor ] if @xmath5 is a finite group with a normal subgroup @xmath60 and @xmath70 is an element of prime order not dividing the order of @xmath60 , then , by a standard argument in group theory ( see for example  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  1.6.2 ) ) the centraliser of @xmath45 in @xmath5 and the centraliser of @xmath128 in @xmath129 are related by the following formula :    @xmath130    an analogous formula holds for the normaliser of the group generated by @xmath45 :    @xmath131    [ prop : quotient action ] let @xmath69 be a finite group acting on a @xmath28-sphere @xmath2 and let @xmath60 be a normal subgroup of @xmath5 . if @xmath45 is a rotation of order @xmath8 such that @xmath8 is coprime with the order of @xmath60 , then the normaliser of a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath129 contains ( up to conjugacy ) @xmath132 with index at most @xmath6 . in particular",
    ", the normaliser of a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath129 contains an abelian subgroup of rank at most @xmath6 with index at most @xmath74 .",
    "let @xmath71 be a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath5 : up to conjugacy we can suppose that @xmath71 contains @xmath45 .",
    "we denote by @xmath133 the projection of @xmath71 to @xmath129 , which is a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath129 .",
    "since @xmath71 is a normal subgroup of @xmath77 , by remark  [ rem : centralizer - factor ] we obtain that @xmath133 is normal in @xmath134 , thus @xmath135 .",
    "the group @xmath129 acts on the manifold @xmath136 . indeed ,",
    "althought @xmath60 may not act freely , the space of orbits @xmath136 is a manifold for the diffeomorphisms in @xmath5 preserve the orientation of @xmath2 .",
    "let @xmath137 be a non - trivial element of @xmath71 such that @xmath138 has order @xmath8 and has non - empty fixed - point set with respect to its action on @xmath136 .",
    "this can be rephrased by saying that there is @xmath139 and @xmath140 such that @xmath141 , so that @xmath66 maps to a fixed point of @xmath138 in @xmath136 .",
    "we thus see that there exists @xmath142 acting on @xmath2 with non - empty fixed - point set , where @xmath143 .",
    "since @xmath144 projects to @xmath138 , we obtain that the order of @xmath144 is a multiple of @xmath8 .",
    "let @xmath145 be a non trivial power of @xmath144 of order @xmath8 .",
    "note that , since @xmath146 , @xmath145 has non - empty fixed - point set .",
    "the element @xmath145 is contained in @xmath147 , the subgroup of @xmath5 generated by @xmath71 and @xmath60 . since by proposition  [ pro : sylow ] the sylow @xmath8-subgroup @xmath71 is abelian , @xmath145 is conjugated by an element of @xmath60 to an element of @xmath71 of order @xmath8 .",
    "we can conclude that the cyclic group generated by @xmath138 is the projection of one cyclic subgroup of @xmath71 of order @xmath8 generated by elements with non - empty fixed - point set .",
    "since @xmath71 contains at most two of these subgroups ( proposition  [ pro : sylow ] ) , @xmath133 has the same property and the thesis follows .",
    "[ rem : otherwise ]    obviously , proposition  [ prop : quotient action ] applies whenever @xmath5 contains a hyperelliptic rotation @xmath45 of odd prime order @xmath8 ( see remark  [ rem : coverings ] ) .",
    "more generally , though , its proof is valid whenever the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath5 contains at most two cyclic subgroups generated by elements with non - empty fixed - point sets and at least one generated by a rotation , just as in the setting of proposition  [ pro : hyperellipticnormsylow ] , without any condition on the homology of @xmath2 .    if @xmath2 is a @xmath28-homology sphere we can give a different and more geometric proof by observing that the manifold @xmath136 on which @xmath129 acts is again a @xmath28-homology sphere",
    "proposition  [ prop : quotient action ] then follows from remark  [ rem : centralizer - factor ] and proposition  [ pro : sylow ] .    to see that @xmath136 is a @xmath28-homology sphere , consider the following exact sequence @xmath148 where @xmath149 denotes the orbifold fundamental group of the orbifold structure of @xmath136 .",
    "the above exact sequence gives : @xmath150 for the group @xmath151 is characteristic and contained in @xmath152 .",
    "since both @xmath153 and @xmath60 are finite and of order prime with @xmath8 so are @xmath154 and its quotient , the abelianisation of @xmath149 .",
    "we now observe that @xmath149 must surject onto @xmath155 , the fundamental group of the manifold @xmath136 , so that the abelianisation of @xmath149 must surject on the homology of @xmath136 , proving the assertion .",
    "this argument shows something more precise that what claimed in the statement of proposition  [ prop : quotient action ] , namely that the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath129 , which is isomorphic to @xmath71 , acts on @xmath136 precisely as @xmath71 acts on @xmath2 .",
    "recall that a finite group @xmath156 is _ quasisimple _ if it is perfect ( the abelianised group is trivial ) and the factor group @xmath157 of @xmath156 by its centre @xmath158 is a nonabelian simple group ( see @xcite ) .",
    "a group @xmath159 is _ semisimple _ if it is perfect and the factor group @xmath160 is a direct product of nonabelian simple groups .",
    "a semisimple group @xmath159 is a central product of quasisimple groups which are uniquely determined .",
    "any finite group @xmath5 has a unique maximal semisimple normal subgroup @xmath161 ( maybe trivial ) , which is characteristic in @xmath5 .",
    "the subgroup @xmath161 is called the _ layer _ of @xmath5 and the quasisimple factors of @xmath161 are called the _",
    "components _ of @xmath5 .",
    "the maximal normal nilpotent subgroup of a finite group @xmath5 is called the _ fitting subgroup _ and is usually denoted by @xmath162 .",
    "the fitting subgroup commutes elementwise with the layer of @xmath5",
    ". the normal subgroup generated by @xmath161 and by @xmath162 is called the _ generalised fitting subgroup _ and is usually denoted by @xmath163 .",
    "the generalised fitting subgroup has the important property to contain its centraliser in @xmath5 , which thus coincides with the centre of @xmath163 . for further properties of the generalised fitting subgroup see ( * ? ?",
    "* section 6.6 . ) .",
    "let @xmath29 be a finite group acting on a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2",
    ". in the following it will be convenient to consider @xmath164 , _ the maximal normal solvable subgroup of odd order coprime with any hyperelliptic prime for @xmath5 _ and @xmath165 , _ the maximal normal solvable subgroup of order coprime with any hyperelliptic prime for @xmath5 _ , not necessarily odd ( for the existence of @xmath164 and @xmath165 see  @xcite ) .",
    "[ prop : fitting - layer ] let @xmath29 be a finite group acting on a @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 not homeomorphic to @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath164 and @xmath165 be defined as above .",
    "let @xmath166 ( respectively @xmath167 ) be the fitting subgroup of @xmath168 ( respectively @xmath169 ) and let @xmath170 ( respectively @xmath171 ) be the layer of @xmath168 ( respectively @xmath169 ) .",
    "assume that one of the following conditions is satisfied :    * the maximal normal subgroup of odd order of the fitting subgroup @xmath166 ( respectively @xmath167 ) is not cyclic ; * the fitting subgroup @xmath166 ( respectively @xmath167 ) is cyclic and the layer @xmath170 ( respectively @xmath171 ) is trivial ;    then @xmath5 is solvable .    by the maximality of @xmath164",
    "we obtain that the odd primes dividing the order of @xmath166 are hyperelliptic .",
    "if the maximal subgroup of @xmath166 of odd order is not cyclic , then there is at least one hyperelliptic odd prime @xmath8 such that the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath166 is abelian of rank @xmath6 , according to remark  [ rem : centralizer - factor ] and proposition  [ pro : sylow ] . since @xmath166 is nilpotent , its sylow subgroups are characteristic . as a consequence ,",
    "@xmath168 normalises the elementary abelian @xmath8-group of rank @xmath6 contained in @xmath166 .",
    "such elementary abelian @xmath8-group contains a projection of a hyperelliptic rotation : by proposition  [ prop : quotient action ] we obtain that @xmath168 , and hence @xmath5 , are solvable groups .",
    "the proof of the situation where @xmath167 is not cyclic follows the same lines .    if @xmath170 is trivial , then the generalised fitting subgroup of @xmath168 coincides with @xmath166 . in this case",
    "we also have that the fitting subgroup coincides with its centraliser in @xmath168 .",
    "since the automorphism group of a cyclic group is abelian , so is @xmath172 which injects into @xmath173 .",
    "we deduce once more that @xmath5 is solvable .",
    "the very same argument gives the proof in the case where @xmath168 is replaced with @xmath169 .",
    "[ r : simple1 ] the proof of the following proposition will rely on the full classification of finite simple groups and , more specifically , on the fact that the structure of their automorphism groups is known .",
    "[ prop : projections ] let @xmath29 be a finite group acting on a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 .",
    "let @xmath60 be a normal subgroup of @xmath5 and let @xmath174 be a rotation of odd prime order @xmath8 , coprime with @xmath175 . if @xmath176 , then the projections to @xmath129 of the rotations of order @xmath8 in @xmath5 are contained in the group generated by @xmath177 and by its centraliser in @xmath129 , and every component of @xmath129 has order divisible by @xmath8 .",
    "moreover , if @xmath178 is cyclic , then the centraliser of @xmath177 in @xmath129 is solvable .",
    "note that by remark  [ rem : normaliser ] and by remark  [ rem : centralizer - factor ] the centraliser of @xmath128 in @xmath129 is abelian .",
    "first we prove that each component of @xmath129 is normalised by @xmath128 .",
    "let @xmath179 be a component of @xmath129 and suppose by contradiction that @xmath179 is not normalised by @xmath128 .",
    "we denote by @xmath180 the coset @xmath128 and by @xmath181 the minimum positive integer such that @xmath182 .",
    "we define the following subgroup :    @xmath183    since elements of @xmath129 contained in different components commute , it is possible to prove that @xmath184 is a subgroup of @xmath129 isomorphic to a quotient of @xmath179 by a central subgroup , i.e. @xmath184 is a quasisimple group .",
    "moreover , each element of @xmath184 commutes with @xmath180 and this is a contradiction to the fact that @xmath180 has abelian centraliser in @xmath129 .",
    "hence @xmath128 normalises @xmath179 .",
    "moreover , for the very same reason , the action by conjugation of @xmath180 on @xmath179 is not trivial .",
    "we remark that the automorphism group of @xmath179 injects in the automorphism group of its simple quotient ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* corollary 5.1.4 ) )    assume that the simple quotient of @xmath179 is either sporadic or alternating . since the order of the outer automorphism group of any such simple group is a ( possibly trivial )",
    "power of @xmath6 ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 5.2 and 5.3 ) ) , we conclude that @xmath180 must induce an inner automorphism of @xmath179 .",
    "in particular @xmath8 divides the order of @xmath179 .",
    "we can thus assume that @xmath179 is a central extension of a simple group of lie type .",
    "recall that , by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  2.5.12 ) , @xmath185 injects to the semidirect product of a normal subgroup @xmath186 , containing the subgroup @xmath187 of inner automorphisms , and a group @xmath188 , where , roughly speaking , @xmath189 is the group of automorphisms of @xmath179 induced by the automorphisms of the defining field and @xmath190 is the group of automorphisms of @xmath179 induced by the symmetries of the dinking diagram associated to @xmath179 ( see @xcite for the exact definition ) . by (",
    "* theorem  2.5.12.(c ) ) , every prime divisor of @xmath191 divides @xmath192 .",
    "thus we can assume that the automorphism induced by @xmath180 on @xmath179 is not contained in @xmath186 and its projection @xmath193 on @xmath194 has order @xmath8 .",
    "we will find a contradiction showing that in this case the centraliser of @xmath180 in @xmath179 is not abelian .",
    "write @xmath195 , with @xmath196 and @xmath197 .",
    "if @xmath198 , then @xmath199 is nontrivial and @xmath180 induces a graph automorphism according to ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition 2.5.13 ) . since @xmath8 is odd",
    ", the only possibility is that @xmath179 is a central perfect extension of @xmath200 and @xmath201 ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 2.5.12 ( e ) ) ) .",
    "the centraliser of @xmath180 in @xmath179 is nonabelian by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* table  4.7.3 and proposition 4.9.2 . ) .",
    "if @xmath202 and @xmath179 is not isomorphic to the group @xmath203 , then the structure of the centraliser of @xmath180 in @xmath179 is described by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  4.9.1 ) , and it is nonabelian . finally , if @xmath202 and @xmath204 , the structure of the non abelian centraliser of @xmath180 in @xmath179 follows from ( * ? ? ? * proposition  4.2.4 ) .",
    "we proved that the automorphism induced by @xmath180 is contained in @xmath186 and @xmath8 divides @xmath192 .",
    "let us now assume by contradiction that the projection to @xmath129 of a rotation of order @xmath8 in @xmath5 is not contained in the group generated by @xmath177 and its centraliser in @xmath129 .",
    "denote by @xmath44 such rotation , by @xmath71 the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath129 containing @xmath205 and by @xmath206 the centraliser of @xmath177 in @xmath129 .",
    "note that @xmath207 .",
    "we recall that , by proposition  [ pro : sylow ] , @xmath71 is abelian of rank at most @xmath6 .",
    "since @xmath8 divides the order of every component of @xmath129 and @xmath71 has rank at most @xmath6 , we get that @xmath177 has only one component , @xmath179 , with cyclic sylow @xmath8-subgroup .",
    "moreover , by the first part of the proof , the automorphism induced by @xmath208 on @xmath179 is inner - diagonal .",
    "if it is inner , we obtain @xmath208 as a product of an element that centralises @xmath179 and an element in @xmath209 otherwise , we get a contradiction , since , by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  2.5.12 ) and ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ( 33.14 ) ) , a group of lie type with cyclic sylow @xmath8-subgroup can not have a diagonal automorphism of order @xmath8 .",
    "since the centraliser of the generalised fitting subgroup coincides with its centre @xmath210 and since @xmath206 acts trivially on @xmath177 by definition , the quotient @xmath211 merges injectively in the automorphism group of @xmath178 .",
    "if the fitting subgroup is cyclic , then its automorphism group is abelian and @xmath206 is solvable .",
    "in this section we prove theorem  [ th : main3 ] under the assumption that the finite group @xmath5 of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of the closed orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 contains a hyperelliptic rotation whose order @xmath3 is not a power of @xmath6 and which corresponds to a cyclic cover of @xmath1 branched along a non - self symmetric knot @xmath41 .    the main result of this section is the following :    [ thm : hyp - bound ]",
    "let @xmath36 be the @xmath3-fold cyclic covering of @xmath1 branched along a knot @xmath102 such that @xmath3 is not a power of @xmath6 .",
    "let @xmath5 be a finite subgroup of @xmath212 which contains the group of deck transformations of the @xmath3-fold cyclic branched covering of @xmath41 .",
    "assume that @xmath41 is not self - symmetric with respect to @xmath5 .",
    "then @xmath5 contains at most six conjugacy classes of cyclic groups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order .",
    "[ rem : algebraic - condition ] according to definition  [ def : relg ] and proposition  [ prop : symmetries and normalizer ] , the hypothesis that @xmath41 is not self - symmetric with respect to @xmath5 is equivalent to the following algebraic condition : for each odd prime @xmath8 dividing @xmath3 the normaliser of a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath5 coincides with the normaliser of a rotation of order @xmath8 ( see also lemma  [ lem : commuting powers suffice ] ) .",
    "it is in fact this equivalent condition that is used in the proofs of theorem  [ thm : knots ] in @xcite and of theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] .",
    "the following two theorems , proved in @xcite , are key results for the proof of theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] .",
    "let us remark that their proofs only rely on the gorenstein - harada theorem @xcite and not on the whole classification of simple groups .",
    "[ thm : special ] ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 2 ) let @xmath5 be a finite group of orientation - preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold .",
    "let @xmath213 be its maximal normal subgroup of odd order and @xmath214 be the layer of @xmath215 .",
    "if @xmath5 contains a rotation of order @xmath6 , @xmath216 , such that the coset @xmath217 is contained in @xmath214 , then @xmath215 has a normal subgroup @xmath218 isomorphic to one of the following groups : @xmath219 where @xmath15 and @xmath220 are odd prime powers greater than @xmath74 .",
    "the factor group @xmath221 contains , with index at most @xmath6 , an abelian subgroup of rank at most @xmath74 .",
    "let @xmath2 be the @xmath3-fold and @xmath222-fold cyclic branched cover of two knots @xmath41 and @xmath223 , respectively .",
    "we denote by @xmath40 and @xmath224 the corresponding cyclic groups of deck transformations for @xmath41 and @xmath223 , respectively .",
    "we shall say that the knots @xmath41 and @xmath223 _ arise from the standard abelian construction _ if the groups @xmath40 and @xmath224 commute up to conjugacy .",
    "this happens if and only if @xmath41 ( respectively @xmath223 ) admits a full rotation @xmath225 induced by the generator of @xmath224 ( respectively @xmath216 induced by the generator of @xmath40 ) of order @xmath222 ( respectively @xmath3 ) ( see also remark  [ rem : full iff hyperelliptic ] ) and such that @xmath226 .",
    "the following result is stated in @xcite under the extra hypothesis that @xmath2 is hyperbolic .",
    "hyperbolicity of the manifold @xmath2 is only used in the proof to ensure that the covering transformations for @xmath41 and @xmath223 sit inside a finite group of diffeomorphisms and that @xmath41 and @xmath223 are not trivial .",
    "the conditions given here replace thus the hyperbolicity requirement .",
    "[ thm : knots ] ( * ? ? ? * theorem 3 ) let @xmath2 be a @xmath0-manifold not homeomorphic to @xmath1 .",
    "suppose that @xmath2 is the @xmath3-fold and @xmath222-fold cyclic covering of @xmath1 branched along two distinct knots @xmath41 and @xmath223 , respectively , such that @xmath222 and @xmath3 are not powers of @xmath6 .",
    "let @xmath5 be a finite subgroup of @xmath212 which contains the corresponding cyclic groups of deck transformations for @xmath41 and @xmath223 , respectively .",
    "if the knot @xmath41 is not self - symmetric with respect to @xmath5 , then one of the following cases occurs :    1 .",
    "@xmath41 and @xmath223 arise from the standard abelian construction ; 2 .",
    "if @xmath227 is the maximal normal subgroup of odd order , @xmath5 contains a rotation @xmath216 of order @xmath6 such that @xmath217 is contained in the layer of @xmath215 ( in particular theorem  [ thm : special ] applies to @xmath5 ) ; 3 .",
    "all prime divisors of @xmath3 and @xmath222 are contained in @xmath228 and there exists a normal subgroup @xmath60 of @xmath5 such that @xmath60 is solvable and @xmath129 is isomorphic to a subgroup of @xmath229 .",
    "to prove theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] the strategy is to  cover \" the group @xmath5 with solvable groups . with this in mind ,",
    "we introduce the notion of solvable normal @xmath230-cover .",
    "let @xmath5 be a finite group .",
    "let @xmath230 be a set of primes dividing @xmath231 .",
    "we will call a collection @xmath232 of subgroups of @xmath5 a _",
    "solvable normal @xmath230-cover _ of @xmath5 if every element of @xmath5 of prime order @xmath8 belonging to @xmath230 is contained in an element of @xmath232 and for every @xmath137 , @xmath233 we have that @xmath234 .",
    "we denote by @xmath235 the smallest number of conjugacy classes of subgroups in a solvable normal @xmath230-cover of @xmath5 .",
    "note that , since sylow subgroups are clearly solvable , latexmath:[$\\gamma^s_{\\pi}(g)\\leq     notice that our definition of solvable normal @xmath230-cover differs from the more usual definition of _ normal cover for non - cyclic finite groups _ in that we only need to cover elements of prime order and not elements of arbitrary order . also the subgroups of a solvable normal @xmath230-cover must be solvable but need not be proper .",
    "the following remark better explains the reason why we are interested in  covering \" @xmath5 with solvable groups .",
    "[ rem : upper bound ] if @xmath5 is a finite group of orientation - preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 and @xmath230 is the set of hyperelliptic primes for @xmath5 , then , by theorem  [ th : solvable ] , the number @xmath237 bounds from above the number of non conjugate cyclic groups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order .",
    "this algebraic lemma , whose proof is straightforward , will be useful .    [",
    "lem : quotient ] let @xmath5 be a finite group , and let @xmath230 be a set of primes dividing the order of @xmath5 .",
    "* if @xmath60 is a solvable normal subgroup of @xmath5 , then @xmath238 .",
    "* if @xmath239 is a subset of @xmath230 , then @xmath240 .",
    "we are now ready to prove theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] .",
    "* proof of theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] .",
    "*    let @xmath45 be a hyperelliptic rotation of @xmath2 generating the group of deck transformations of the @xmath3-fold cyclic branched covering of @xmath41",
    ". we can apply theorem  [ thm : knots ] to deduce that either all the other hyperelliptic rotations commute with @xmath45 , up to conjugacy , or one of situations 2 . or 3 .",
    "occurs .",
    "if all hyperelliptic rotations commute with @xmath45 , it follows from proposition  [ prop : commuting rotations ] that their number , including @xmath45 , is at most three .",
    "if we are in situation 3 , the factor @xmath129 has , up to conjugacy , at most three sylow subgroups of odd order . choosing a sylow subgroup of @xmath129 for each prime in @xmath241 , the preimages of these subgroups in @xmath5 are three solvable subgroups containing @xmath60 such that their conjugates give a solvable normal @xmath230-cover , where @xmath230 is the set of odd primes dividing the order of @xmath5 .",
    "therefore , if a hyperelliptic rotation is contained in @xmath60 all the other rotations of odd order commute with it and we are done .    otherwise , the hyperelliptic primes are contained in the set @xmath241 . by lemma  [ lem:2rot ] and proposition  [ pro : sylow ] , there are in @xmath5 at most six non conjugate cyclic groups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order .",
    "finally we assume that condition 2 of theorem  [ thm : knots ] holds and @xmath5 is one of the groups described in theorem  [ thm : special ] .    as in section",
    "[ sec : finite action ] and proposition  [ prop : fitting - layer ] we will consider @xmath164 , the maximal normal solvable subgroup of @xmath5 whose order is odd and coprime with any hyperelliptic prime . if @xmath8 is a hyperelliptic prime , since @xmath242 and @xmath8 are coprime , the projections of the rotations of order @xmath8 to @xmath168 have abelian centraliser ( see remark  [ rem : centralizer - factor ] ) .",
    "we have @xmath243 , the maximal normal subgroup of odd order , so the layer of @xmath168 , which may be trivial , projects to a normal semisimple subgroup of @xmath215 with the same number of quasisimple factors as the layer of @xmath168 .",
    "hence , any component of @xmath168 is a central perfect extension of @xmath244 ; moreover in @xmath168 we have at most two components .",
    "remark that , although the layer @xmath214 can not be trivial for it contains @xmath217 , the layer @xmath170 might be trivial a priori .",
    "let us now consider the fitting subgroup @xmath166 of @xmath168 . by proposition  [ prop : fitting - layer ]",
    ", we can assume that the maximal normal subgroup of @xmath166 of odd order is cyclic .",
    "we will now prove that @xmath166 itself is cyclic .",
    "since @xmath166 is nilpotent , this boils down to showing that the sylow @xmath6-subgroup of @xmath166 is cyclic ( or possibly trivial ) .",
    "the sylow @xmath6-subgroup of @xmath166 projects injectively to a subgroup of the fitting subgroup of @xmath215 ; in the final step of the proof of theorem  [ thm : special ] it is proved that @xmath245 is cyclic , which is enough to reach the desired conclusion .",
    "we provide here the proof of this fact for completeness .",
    "we remark that , by the maximality of @xmath213 , @xmath245 is a @xmath6-group and the layer of @xmath215 contains @xmath217 where @xmath216 is a rotation of order @xmath6 .",
    "the centraliser of @xmath216 is described in remark  [ rem : normaliser ] and by remark  [ rem : centralizer - factor ] we can deduce that the structure of the centraliser of @xmath217 in @xmath215 is analogous . if the layer of @xmath215 is isomorphic to @xmath244 , the sylow @xmath6-subgroup of @xmath214 is dihedral and @xmath217 is centralised by an elementary abelian @xmath6-subgroup of rank @xmath6 , this implies that @xmath245 has order @xmath6 . if the layer of @xmath215 is @xmath246 , the quotient of @xmath214 by its centre contains an elementary abelian @xmath6-subgroup of rank @xmath74 that is centralised by @xmath247 . since each @xmath6-subgroup of @xmath5 is generated by at most four elements ( see  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 2.2 . ) ) , then @xmath245 coincides with the centre of the layer .    since @xmath245 is a cyclic group of order a ( possibly trivial ) power of @xmath6 , @xmath166 is cyclic . by proposition  [ prop : fitting - layer ]",
    "we can assume that the layer @xmath170 is not trivial .",
    "by proposition  [ prop : projections ] we can suppose that @xmath168 coincides with the group generated by @xmath170 and by a normal solvable subgroup ( the centraliser of the layer ) .",
    "by lemma  [ lem : quotient ] and remark  [ rem : upper bound ] , we obtain that the number of conjugacy classes of subgroups of @xmath5 generated by some hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order is bounded by @xmath248 , where @xmath230 is the set of odd primes dividing the order of @xmath170 .",
    "we recall that the number @xmath249 is two .",
    "in fact the upper triangular matrices form a solvable subgroup of @xmath250 of order @xmath251 , moreover @xmath250 contains a cyclic subgroup of order @xmath252 ( see  @xcite ) .",
    "the conjugates of the projections of these two subgroups to @xmath244 give a solvable normal @xmath230-cover .",
    "if @xmath168 has one component , then we obtain that six is an upper bound for the number of conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups of @xmath5 generated by hyperelliptic rotations .",
    "if @xmath168 has two components , the same argument implies readily that twelve is an upper bound but in this case , with a small modification of our reasoning , we are able to get that there are at most four hyperellitpic primes .",
    "suppose that the components of @xmath168 are two ; the layer of @xmath168 projects surjectively to the layer of @xmath215 .",
    "a central perfect extension of @xmath244 that is not simple has a center of order @xmath6 , with the only exception of @xmath253 . in this case",
    "the centre might contain some element of order @xmath0 but , if a component of @xmath168 is a central perfect extension of @xmath254 with centre containing an element of order @xmath0 , then the sylow @xmath0-subgroup is not abelian ( see  @xcite ) , and hence @xmath0 can not be hyperelliptic ; this contradicts the maximality of @xmath164 .",
    "we thus obtain that the layer of @xmath168 is @xmath255 ( we remark that @xmath15 and @xmath220 might be equal ) . by proposition  [ prop : projections ] a hyperelliptic prime number @xmath8 divides the order of both components , this implies that the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath170 is abelian of rank @xmath6 , and all the projections of the rotations of order @xmath8 to @xmath168 are contained in the layer of @xmath168 .",
    "we denote by @xmath256 the subgroup of the upper triangular matrices of @xmath250 and by @xmath257 a cyclic subgroup of order @xmath252 of @xmath250 .",
    "we consider the following set of solvable subgroups of @xmath255 : @xmath258 this set has the property that each sylow @xmath8-subgroup in @xmath168 with @xmath8 odd is contained in a conjugate of one of the subgroups in @xmath259 we consider the preimages of the subgroups in @xmath260 with respect to the projection @xmath261 .",
    "we obtain a set @xmath262 containing four solvable subgroups of @xmath5 with the same property ( i.e. each sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath5 with @xmath8 odd is contained in a conjugate of one of the subgroups in @xmath262 ) .",
    "in this situation , if @xmath8 is a hyperelliptic prime , its sylow @xmath8-subgroup has rank @xmath6 . by theorem",
    "[ th : solvable ] , if one subgroup of @xmath262 contains the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of a hyperelliptic prime , then it can not contain any other hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order .",
    "therefore we have at most four hyperelliptic primes .",
    "for each of them we have at most two non conjugate cyclic subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation according to lemma  [ lem:2rot ] .",
    "we will prove that in every case we have only one conjugacy class .",
    "in general this would imply that four is an upper bound ( we use this fact later in the proof of lemma  [ lemma : bivio ] ) but , under the assumption of this theorem that at least one knot is non self - symmetric , this fact implies also that this case does not occur .    if @xmath8 is a hyperelliptic prime and @xmath263 ( where @xmath264 ) , the component @xmath250 contains an involution acting dihedrally on the sylow @xmath8-subgroup by conjugation .",
    "this involution commutes with the other component of @xmath170 , and in particular with the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath265 . by remark  [ rem : conjugate - rotations ]",
    ", we obtain that the two cyclic groups of order @xmath8 generated by elements with non - empty fixed - point set and contained in a sylow @xmath8-subgroup are conjugate .",
    "let @xmath71 be a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath5 ; we denote by @xmath45 and @xmath64 two rotations of order @xmath8 that are contained in @xmath71 and generate different groups . their projections to @xmath168 generate also different cylic groups . replacing @xmath45 with one of its powers",
    ", we can suppose that the projections of @xmath45 and @xmath64 to @xmath168 are conjugate .",
    "thus there exist @xmath266 and @xmath137 such that @xmath267 .",
    "the subgroup generated by @xmath71 and @xmath164 contains @xmath268 , then , by the sylow theorems there exist @xmath269 and @xmath270 such that @xmath271 is contained in @xmath71 .",
    "we remark that @xmath272 has non - empty fixed - point set , so it is contained either in the group generated by @xmath64 or in the group generated by @xmath45 . in the first case",
    "we obtain that the two cyclic groups of order @xmath8 generated by rotations in @xmath71 are conjugate .",
    "the second case can not occur because , if @xmath273 in the quotient @xmath168 we would have that @xmath274 and @xmath275 which is impossible .",
    "we have only one conjugacy class of subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of order @xmath8 .",
    "it remains the case when @xmath276 ; since the sylow @xmath8-subgroup has to be cyclic , in this case @xmath277 .",
    "since @xmath278 we have again elements in @xmath250 that normalise the sylow @xmath8-subgroup but do not centralise it , and hence we have in @xmath168 one conjugacy class of cyclic groups of order @xmath8 generated by rotations and the conclusion follows as in the previous case .    [ rem : not possible ]",
    "the proof of theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] shows that if one of the knots is non self - symmetric with respect to @xmath5 and we have more than three classes of cyclic groups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime order , then either we are in case 3 of theorem  [ thm : knots ] and any hyperelliptic prime is contained in @xmath241 or the layer of @xmath215 is @xmath244 .    taking into account the list of all finite non solvable groups that can possibly act on @xmath9-homology @xmath0-spheres obtained in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 1 , page 677 ) , the proof of theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] and its generalisation to arbitrary orders that are not powers of @xmath6 ( see section  [ sec : generalization ] ) show readily the result below .",
    "we stress that the proof of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 1 , page 677 ) is based on the gorenstein - harada theorem only .",
    "[ cor : z2spheres ] let @xmath36 be a @xmath9-homology sphere .",
    "then @xmath5 contains at most six conjugacy classes of cyclic groups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of order different from a power of @xmath6 .",
    "in this section we complete the proof of theorem  [ th : main3 ] .",
    "th : main3 let @xmath5 be a finite group of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 not homeomorphic to @xmath1 , then @xmath5 contains at most six conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime order .    this general upper bound",
    "is given by theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] of the previous section and by the analysis of the structure of a finite group acting on a closed orientable manifold and containing several hyperelliptic rotations corresponding to deck transformations of cyclic branched coverings along self - symmetric knots .",
    "[ lemma : bivio ] let @xmath5 be a finite group acting by orientation preserving diffeomorphisms on a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath36 .",
    "either theorem  [ th : main3 ] holds for @xmath5 , or there exists @xmath279 a subgroup of @xmath5 such that for any hyperelliptic prime @xmath8 the following properties hold :    1 .",
    "@xmath279 contains all rotations of order @xmath8 up to conjugacy ; 2 .",
    "@xmath53 , a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath279 , has rank two ; 3 .",
    "if @xmath45 is a rotation of order @xmath8 the normaliser @xmath280 is abelian of rank two ; 4 .",
    "@xmath280 is a subgroup of index two of @xmath281 .",
    "we suppose the existence of at least one hyperelliptic prime , otherwise the theorem is automatically verified",
    ".    if for some hyperelliptic prime @xmath8 and for some hyperelliptic rotation @xmath45 of order @xmath8 we have that @xmath282 , then we can apply theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] ( see remark  [ rem : algebraic - condition ] ) and thus theorem [ th : main3 ] holds for @xmath5 .",
    "so we can suppose that for any hyperelliptic prime @xmath73 has index @xmath6 in @xmath283 , thus @xmath53 is of rank @xmath6 and it contains exactly two groups of odd prime order generated by hyperelliptic rotations .",
    "now suppose that @xmath77 is not abelian , hence it contains some @xmath67-inversion of order @xmath6 .",
    "let @xmath216 be such an involution , it projects to a strong inversion of the knot given by the projection of @xmath67 in @xmath284 .",
    "the projection of @xmath216 is a rotation and its axis meets the projection of @xmath67 in two points .",
    "this implies that @xmath216 is a rotation , too . in (",
    "* theorem 1 ) the structure of a finite group acting on a @xmath0-manifold and containing a rotation of order @xmath6 was studied :    [ thm : involution]@xcite let @xmath5 be a finite group of orientation - preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold .",
    "let @xmath213 be the maximal normal subgroup of odd order and @xmath285 be the layer of @xmath286 .",
    "suppose that @xmath5 contains an involution which is a rotation .    1 .",
    "if the semisimple group @xmath287 is not trivial , it has at most two components and the factor group of @xmath288 is solvable .",
    "moreover , the factor group of @xmath289 by its centre is either a simple group of sectional @xmath6-rank at most @xmath74 or the direct product of two simple groups of sectional @xmath6-rank at most @xmath6 .",
    "if @xmath289 is trivial , there exists a normal subgroup @xmath40 of @xmath5 such that @xmath40 is solvable and @xmath290 is isomorphic to a subgroup of @xmath229 , the general linear group of @xmath291 matrices over the finite field with @xmath6 elements .",
    "if @xmath289 is trivial we obtain at most six non conjugate groups of hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime orders ( see the proof of theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] , situation 3 )    if the projection to @xmath292 of a rotation of order @xmath6 is contained in @xmath285 , then theorem  [ thm : special ] applies .",
    "once again the proof of theorem  [ thm : hyp - bound ] implies that six is an upper bound .",
    "we can therefore suppose that @xmath289 is not trivial and the projection of any rotation of order @xmath6 is not contained in @xmath285 .",
