    "the quotient @xmath293 is solvable , by hall s theorem we have a subgroup @xmath294 ( maybe trivial ) of @xmath293 such that the order of @xmath294 is divided only by hyperelliptic primes and the index of @xmath294 in @xmath293 is coprime with each hyperelliptic prime .",
    "we denote by @xmath279 the preimage of @xmath294 in @xmath5 under the projection @xmath295 : the subgroup @xmath279 contains all the sylow subgroups corresponding to hyperelliptic primes and does not contain any rotation of order @xmath6 .",
    "this implies that in @xmath279 a hyperelliptic rotation does not admit inversions and the normaliser of the subgroup it generates is abelian .",
    "the subgroup @xmath279 satisfies our requests , except possibly the fourth , but the case when @xmath296 was analysed at the beginning of the proof giving that theorem  [ th : main3 ] holds for @xmath279 and hence for @xmath5 , since @xmath279 contains all the hyperelliptic rotations of @xmath5 .",
    "* proof of theorem [ th : main3 ] . *",
    "the proof follows from proposition  [ prop : self - symmetric ] below since either theorem [ th : main3 ] holds for @xmath5 or lemma  [ lemma : bivio ] allows to replace @xmath5 by a subgroup @xmath279 , which satisfies the hypotheses of proposition  [ prop : self - symmetric ] .",
    "the rest of the section is devoted to the proof of proposition  [ prop : self - symmetric ] .",
    "[ prop : self - symmetric ] let @xmath5 be a finite group acting by diffeomorphisms on a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 not homeomorphic to @xmath1 . if for any hyperelliptic prime @xmath8 of @xmath5 the following properties hold :    1 .",
    "@xmath53 , a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath5 , is abelian of rank @xmath6 ; 2 .",
    "if @xmath45 is a rotation of order @xmath8 the normaliser @xmath73 is abelian of rank @xmath6 ; 3 .",
    "@xmath73 is a subgroup of index @xmath6 of @xmath283    then we have in @xmath5 at most four non conjugate cyclic subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime orders .    if @xmath8 is a hyperelliptic prime , then @xmath53 has rank @xmath6 and contains exactly two subgroups of order @xmath8 generated by a rotation .",
    "we denote by @xmath297 and @xmath298 , these subgroups .",
    "the quotient of @xmath2 by each of them is homeomorphic to @xmath1 because they are conjugate .",
    "we have that @xmath299 is abelian of rank two and each element in the complement @xmath300 exchanges by conjugation the subgroups @xmath297 and @xmath301    let @xmath165 be the maximal normal solvable subgroup of @xmath5 of order coprime with every hyperelliptic prime ( note that the order of @xmath165 is not necessarily odd ) .",
    "we denote by @xmath302 the factor group of @xmath5 by @xmath165 .",
    "if @xmath66 is an element of @xmath5 we denote by @xmath303 the projection of @xmath66 to @xmath302 , analogously if @xmath40 is a subgroup of @xmath5 , @xmath304 is the projection of @xmath40 to @xmath302 .",
    "[ claim : quotient normaliser ] the sylow @xmath8-subgroup @xmath305 of @xmath302 is abelian of rank @xmath6 .",
    "its normaliser @xmath306 contains @xmath307 with index at most @xmath6 ; @xmath307 is abelian of rank @xmath6 and contains @xmath308 and @xmath309 .",
    "the groups @xmath308 and @xmath309 are the only two cyclic groups of order @xmath8 in @xmath310 acting with non - empty fixed - point sets on the manifold @xmath311 . moreover , either we have at most three non conjugate groups of rotations of odd prime order in @xmath5 or @xmath307 has index exactly @xmath6 in @xmath310 and the elements of @xmath310 not in @xmath307 exchange @xmath308 and @xmath309 .    the first part of the claim is implied by proposition  [ prop : quotient action ] and its proof ; it remains to prove the last statement .",
    "if @xmath312 , then we can apply ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 2.10 . ) and obtain a normal @xmath8-complement @xmath313 .",
    "the preimage of @xmath313 , with respect to the projection of @xmath5 onto @xmath302 , is a normal @xmath8-complement of @xmath5 .",
    "the argument used in the proof of proposition  [ prop : commuting 2 ] shows that in this case rotations of odd prime orders commute up to conjugacy .",
    "thus , the proof of proposition  [ prop : commuting rotations ] shows that in this case we have at most three non conjugate cyclic subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order .    from now on we suppose that @xmath307 has index exactly @xmath6 in @xmath310 .",
    "[ claim : fitting ] let @xmath314 be the fitting subgroup of @xmath302 and let @xmath315 be the layer of @xmath302 .",
    "either we have at most three non conjugate cyclic subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order or @xmath314 is cyclic and @xmath315 is not trivial .",
    "the claim is just proposition  [ prop : fitting - layer ] .    from now on",
    "we suppose that @xmath314 is cyclic and @xmath315 is not trivial .",
    "[ claim : sylow decomposition ] @xmath316 .    since the elements of @xmath317 exchange @xmath308 and @xmath309 , they centralise a subgroup of order @xmath8 of @xmath305 ( see remark  [ rem : conjugate - rotations ] ) and that subgroup is contained in @xmath318 since @xmath307 is abelian . since every element of order @xmath8 in @xmath305 is contained in @xmath319 , we get the assertion .",
    "[ claim : rotations outside ] if a prime @xmath8 is hyperelliptic , then the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath315 is cyclic and non - trivial .",
    "moreover @xmath315 is a simple group .    by (",
    "* exercise 1 , page 161 ) , @xmath305 is the direct product of @xmath320 and @xmath321 , where @xmath322 is the commutator subgroup of @xmath302 . since @xmath305 is abelian of rank @xmath6 and its maximal elementary abelian subgroup is @xmath323 , it follows that @xmath323 is the direct product of @xmath324 and @xmath325 . by claim  [ claim : sylow decomposition ] , @xmath316 .",
    "on the other hand , by proposition  [ prop : projections ] , @xmath326 , since @xmath315 is perfect .",
    "thus , both @xmath324 and @xmath325 are cyclic groups of order @xmath8 .",
    "if @xmath15 is a prime dividing the order of the centre of a component of @xmath302 , according to ( * ?",
    "* ( 33.14 ) ) , the sylow @xmath15-subgroup of the component can not be cyclic , so that @xmath15 is not hyperelliptic .",
    "the maximality of @xmath165 ensures that the centre of @xmath315 is trivial .",
    "it follows that @xmath315 is a simple group with cyclic sylow @xmath8-subgroups .",
    "if we had two components in @xmath302 , then @xmath8 should divide the order of both by proposition  [ prop : projections ] and we would obtain a noncyclic @xmath8-subgroup in @xmath315 ; this is impossible and we have one component .    [",
    "claim : only fitting ] if @xmath8 is hyperelliptic , then the centraliser in @xmath315 of the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath315 is abelian and the normaliser in @xmath315 of the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath315 contains an abelian subgroup of index @xmath6 .    let @xmath45 be a hyperelliptic rotation of order @xmath8 .",
    "by proposition  [ prop : projections ] we have that @xmath180 is contained in the subgroup generated by the the layer and its centraliser .",
    "we obtain that @xmath180 is the product of an element of order @xmath8 in @xmath315 with an element of order @xmath8 that centralises @xmath315 . since the centraliser of @xmath180 is abelian , the centraliser in @xmath315 of any sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath315 is abelian , too .",
    "indeed , any element @xmath327 commutes with any element in the centraliser of @xmath315 . as a consequence , if @xmath66 commutes with an element of order @xmath8 in @xmath315 it commutes with the whole elementary abelian group @xmath323 , and in particular @xmath66 commutes with @xmath180 .",
    "let @xmath305 be a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath302 .",
    "if an element of @xmath315 normalises the sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath315 contained in @xmath305 , then it normalises also the subgroup generated by the elements of order @xmath8 in @xmath305 .",
    "the group @xmath305 contains precisely two cyclic subgroups of order @xmath8 generated by a rotation ( @xmath308 and @xmath309 ) .",
    "therefore the normaliser of a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath315 contains with index @xmath6 an abelian subgroup ( the normaliser can not be abelian otherwise we have a @xmath8-complement ) .",
    "the proof of the following claim will exploit the classification of finite simple groups .",
    "[ claim : final ] the group @xmath5 contains at most four non conjugate cyclic subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime order .",
    "if @xmath315 is sporadic , the primes dividing the order of the group do not satisfy the condition on the normaliser given by claim  [ claim : only fitting ] ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 5.3 . ) ) .",
    "suppose now @xmath328 . if the sylow @xmath8-subgroup is cyclic , then @xmath329 and so the sylow @xmath8-subgroup is generated by a @xmath8-cycle .",
    "since by claim  [ claim : only fitting ] the centraliser is abelian , we have that @xmath330 .",
    "thus we have at most two hyperelliptic odd primes and for each prime we have only one conjugacy class of cyclic groups of order @xmath8 generated by a hyperelliptic rotation .",
    "the only remaining case is that of simple groups of lie type .",
    "we note that each solvable subgroup of @xmath5 contains at most one conjugacy class of cyclic groups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order .",
    "in fact , if @xmath44 were a rotation of odd prime order @xmath15 commuting with a rotation @xmath45 of order @xmath8 , then @xmath44 should be a @xmath67-rotation and centralise a sylow @xmath8-subgroup @xmath53 .",
    "we should obtain that @xmath53 is a group of @xmath331-rotations .",
    "since @xmath331 is a simple closed curve , the action of @xmath53 on @xmath331 can not be faithful and @xmath331 should coincide either with the fixed point of @xmath332 or with that of @xmath333 .",
    "this is impossible by part 2 of lemma  [ lem : commuting powers suffice ] .",
    "therefore , we have that the number of conjugacy classes of subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime order in @xmath5 is bounded by @xmath235 where @xmath230 is the set of hyperelliptic primes . since the fitting subgroup of @xmath302 is cyclic , by proposition  [ prop : projections ] and",

    "* paragraph  4.10 ) , since the sylow subgroups are cyclic , every element of order @xmath353 is contained in a maximal torus of @xmath41 , and clearly a maximal torus is abelian .    therefore , we need only to bound the number of conjugacy classes of cyclic maximal tori in @xmath41 with abelian centraliser .",

    "the statement of theorem [ th : knots ] is equivalent to the following :    [ th : main2 ] let @xmath2 be a closed , orientable , connected , irreducible @xmath0-manifold which is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 , then the group @xmath449 of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of @xmath2 contains at most six conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order .    notice that generically one expects that two hyperelliptic rotations in the group @xmath449 generate an infinite subgroup .      in this section",
    "we prove proposition  [ prop : seifert ] which implies theorem  [ th : main2 ] for closed seifert fibred @xmath0-manifolds .",
    "we also show that the assumption that the hyperelliptic rotations have odd prime orders can not be avoided in general by exhibiting examples of closed seifert fibred @xmath0-manifolds @xmath2 such that @xmath449 contains an arbitrarily large number of conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd , but not prime , orders .",
    "[ prop : seifert ] let @xmath2 be a closed seifert fibred @xmath0-manifold which is not homeomorphic to @xmath1",
    ". then the group @xmath449 of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of @xmath2 contains at most one conjugacy class of cyclic subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order except if @xmath2 is a brieskorn integral homology sphere with @xmath0 exceptional fibres . in this latter case @xmath449",
    "contains at most three non conjugate cyclic subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime orders .    by hypothesis @xmath2",
    "is a cyclic cover of @xmath450 branched over a knot , so it is orientable and a rational homology sphere by remark  [ rem : coverings ] .",
    "notably , @xmath2 can not be @xmath451 nor a euclidean manifold , except for the hantzsche - wendt manifold , see ( * ? ? ? * chap .",
    "8.2 ) . in particular , since @xmath2 is prime it is also irreducible .",
    "consider a hyperelliptic rotation @xmath21 on @xmath2 of odd prime order @xmath8 and let @xmath41 be the image of @xmath22 in the quotient @xmath452 by the action of @xmath21 .",
    "the knot @xmath41 must be hyperbolic or a torus knot , otherwise its exterior would be toroidal and have a non - trivial jsj - collection of essential tori which would lift to a non trivial jsj - collection of tori for @xmath2 , since the order of @xmath21 is @xmath453 ( see @xcite and @xcite ) . by the orbifold theorem",
    "( see @xcite , @xcite ) , the cyclic branched cover with order @xmath454 of a hyperbolic knot is hyperbolic , with a single exception for @xmath455 when @xmath41 is the the figure - eight knot and @xmath2 is the hantzsche - wendt euclidean manifold .",
    "but then , by the orbifold theorem and the classification of @xmath0-dimensional christallographic groups , @xmath21 is the unique , up to conjugacy , euclidean hyperelliptic rotation on @xmath2 , see for example @xcite , @xcite .",
    "so we can assume that @xmath2 is the @xmath8-fold cyclic cover of @xmath1 branched along a non trivial torus knot @xmath41 of type @xmath456 , where @xmath457 and @xmath458 are coprime integers .",
    "then @xmath2 is a brieskorn - pham manifold @xmath459 .",
    "a simple computation shows that @xmath2 admits a seifert fibration with @xmath0 , @xmath8 or @xmath460 exceptional fibres and base space @xmath461 , see ( * ? ? ?",
    "2 ) , or ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 6 and proof of lemma 7 ) .",
    "in particular @xmath2 has a unique seifert fibration , up to isotopy : by @xcite , @xcite and @xcite the only possible exception with base @xmath461 and at least @xmath0 exceptional fibres is the double of a twisted @xmath462-bundle , which is not a rational homology sphere , since it fibers over the circle .",
    "we distinguish now two cases : + * case 1 * : _ the integers @xmath463 and @xmath464 are coprime with @xmath8 , and there are three singular fibres of pairwise relatively prime orders @xmath463 , @xmath464 and @xmath8_. by the orbifold theorem any hyperelliptic rotation of @xmath2 of order @xmath465 is conjugate into the circle action @xmath466 inducing the seifert fibration , hence the uniqueness of the seifert fibration , up to isotopy , implies that @xmath2 admits at most @xmath0 non conjugate cyclic groups generated by hyperelliptic rotations with odd prime orders belonging to @xmath467 .",
    "indeed @xmath2 is a brieskorn integral homology sphere , see @xcite . + * case 2 * : _ either @xmath468 and @xmath2 has @xmath8 singular fibres of order @xmath464 , or @xmath469 with @xmath470 , and @xmath2 has @xmath8 singular fibres of order @xmath464 and one extra singular fibre of order @xmath471 . _ in both situations , there are @xmath454 exceptional fibres of order @xmath464 which are cyclically permuted by the hyperelliptic rotation @xmath21 . as before , @xmath2 has a unique seifert fibration , up to isotopy .",
    "therefore , up to conjugacy , @xmath21 is the only hyperelliptic rotation of order @xmath8 on @xmath2 , and by the discussion above @xmath2 can not admit a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order @xmath472 .    [",
    "rem : brieskorn ] the requirement that the rotations are hyperelliptic is essential in the proof of proposition  [ prop : seifert ] .",
    "the brieskorn homology sphere @xmath473 , with @xmath474 exceptional fibres admits @xmath3 rotations of pairwise distinct prime orders but which are not hyperelliptic .    the hypothesis that the orders of the hyperelliptic rotations are @xmath475 can not be avoided either .",
    "indeed , montesinos construction of fibre preserving hyperelliptic involutions on seifert fibered rational homology spheres @xcite , @xcite , ( see also ( * ? ? ?",
    "* appendix a ) , ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter 12 ) ) , shows that for any given integer @xmath3 there are infinitely many closed orientable seifert fibred @xmath0-manifolds with at least @xmath3 conjugacy classes of hyperelliptic rotations of order @xmath6 .    on the other hand , the hypothesis that the orders are odd primes is sufficient but not necessary : a careful analysis of the seifert invariants shows that if @xmath36 is a seifert rational homology sphere , then @xmath2 can be the cyclic branched cover of a knot in @xmath1 of order @xmath465 in at most three ways .",
    "the hypotheses of proposition  [ prop : seifert ] can not be relaxed further , though : proposition  [ prop : circle bundles ] below shows that there exist closed @xmath0-dimensional circle bundles with arbitrarily many conjugacy classes of hyperelliptic rotations of odd , but not prime , orders .",
    "[ prop : circle bundles ] let @xmath60 be an odd prime integer . for any integer",
    "@xmath476 the brieskorn - pham manifold @xmath477 is a circle bundle over a closed surface of genus @xmath478 with euler class @xmath479 . hence ,",
    "up to homeomorphism ( possibly reversing the orientation ) , @xmath2 depends only on the integer @xmath60 and admits at least @xmath480 conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd orders .",
    "we remark first that the integers @xmath15 and @xmath481 are relatively prime , because @xmath60 is prime .",
    "if @xmath12 is a common prime divisor of @xmath482 and @xmath483 , by bezout identity we have @xmath484 which implies that @xmath485 .",
    "but then @xmath486 and thus @xmath487 which is impossible since @xmath60 is odd .",
    "hence @xmath488 and @xmath483 are relatively prime .",
    "so the brieskorn - pham manifold @xmath2 is the @xmath489-fold cyclic cover of @xmath450 branched over the torus knot @xmath490 .",
    "it is obtained by dehn filling the @xmath491-fold cyclic cover of the exterior of the torus knot @xmath492 along the lift of its meridian .",
    "the @xmath491-fold cyclic cover of the exterior of @xmath492 is a trivial circle bundle over a once punctured surface of genus @xmath493 . on the boundary of the torus - knot exterior the algebraic intersection between a meridian and a fibre of the seifert fibration of the exterior",
    "is @xmath494 ( the sign depends on a choice of orientation , see for example ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter 3 ) ) .",
    "so on the torus boundary of the @xmath491-fold cyclic cover the algebraic intersection between the lift of a meridian of the torus knot and a @xmath495-fiber is again @xmath494 .",
    "hence the circle bundle structure of the @xmath491-fold cyclic cover of the exterior of the torus knot @xmath492 can be extended with euler class @xmath494 to the dehn filling along the lift of the meridian .",
    "so @xmath2 is a circle bundle over a closed surface of genus @xmath478 with euler class @xmath494 .    since the torus knots @xmath490 are pairwise inequivalent for @xmath496 , the cyclic subgroups generated by the hyperelliptic rotations corresponding to the @xmath489-fold cyclic branched covers of the knots @xmath492 are pairwise not conjugate in @xmath212 .",
    "[ r : not finite ] note that the seifert manifolds @xmath2 and their hyperelliptic rotations constructed in proposition  [ prop : circle bundles ] enjoy the following properties : if @xmath497 , then no hyperelliptic rotation can commute up to conjugacy with all the remaining ones ( see theorem  [ th : solvable ] and ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 2 ) ) .",
    "if @xmath498 no finite subgroup of @xmath449 can contain up to conjugacy all hyperelliptic rotations of @xmath2 , according to theorem  [ th : main4 ] .",
    "the fact that theorem  [ th : main2 ] implies corollary  [ th : main ] follows from the existence of a decomposition of a closed , orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 as a connected sum of prime manifolds and the observation that a hyperelliptic rotation on @xmath2 induces a hyperelliptic rotation on each of its prime summands . a @xmath0-manifold",
    "admitting a hypereliptic rotation must be a rational homology sphere , and so @xmath2 can not have @xmath499 summands .",
    "hence all prime summands are irreducible and at least one is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 , since @xmath2 itself is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 .",
    "this is enough to conclude .",
    "+ the remaining of this section is devoted to the proof that theorem  [ th : main3 ] implies theorem  [ th : main2 ] .",
    "we prove the following proposition :    [ prop : finitereduction ] if @xmath2 is a closed , orientable , irreducible @xmath0-manifold such that there are @xmath500 conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups of @xmath212 generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime order , then @xmath2 is homeomorphic to @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath2 be a closed , orientable , irreducible @xmath0-manifold such that @xmath212 contains @xmath500 conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime orders .    according to the orbifold theorem ( see @xcite , @xcite , @xcite ) , a closed orientable irreducible manifold @xmath2 admitting a rotation has geometric decomposition .",
    "this means that @xmath2 can be split along a ( possibly empty ) finite collection of @xmath501-injective embedded tori into submanifolds carrying either a hyperbolic or a seifert fibered structure .",
    "this splitting along tori is unique up to isotopy and is called the jsj - decomposition of @xmath2 , see for example @xcite , @xcite .",
    "in particular , if its jsj - decomposition is trivial , @xmath2 admits either a hyperbolic or a seifert fibred structure .",
    "first we see that @xmath2 can not be hyperbolic . indeed ,",
    "if the manifold @xmath2 is hyperbolic then , by the orbifold theorem , any hyperelliptic rotation is conjugate into the finite group @xmath7 of orientation preserving isometries of @xmath2 .",
    "hence , applying theorem  [ th : main3 ] to @xmath502 , we see that @xmath503 against the hypothesis .",
    "if the manifold @xmath2 is seifert fibred , it follows readily from proposition  [ prop : seifert ] of the previous section that @xmath51 .",
    "so we are left to exclude the case where the jsj - decomposition of @xmath2 is not empty .",
    "consider the jsj - decomposition of @xmath2 : each geometric piece admits either a complete hyperbolic structure with finite volume or a seifert fibred product structure with orientable base .",
    "moreover , the geometry of each piece is unique , up to isotopy .",
    "let @xmath504 be the set of hyperelliptic rotations which generate non conjugate cyclic subgroups in @xmath449 . by the orbifold theorem @xcite , @xcite , @xcite",
    ", after conjugacy , one can assume that each hyperelliptic rotation preserves the jsj - decomposition , acts isometrically on the hyperbolic pieces , and respects the product structure on the seifert pieces .",
    "we say that they are geometric .",
    "let @xmath190 be the dual graph of the jsj - decomposition : it is a tree , for @xmath2 is a rational homology sphere ( in fact , the dual graph of a manifold which is the cyclic branched cover of a knot is always a tree , regardless of the order of the covering ) .",
    "let @xmath505 be the group of diffeomorphisms of @xmath2 generated by the set @xmath506 of geometric hyperelliptic rotations . by ( * ?",
    "* thm 1 ) , there is a subset @xmath507 of @xmath508 hyperelliptic rotations with pairwise distinct odd prime order , say @xmath509 .",
    "let @xmath510 denote the image of the induced representation of @xmath40 in @xmath511 .",
    "since rotations of finite odd order can not induce an inversion on any edge of @xmath190 , the finite group @xmath510 must fix point - wise a non - empty subtree @xmath512 of @xmath190 .",
    "the idea of the proof is now analogous to the ones in @xcite and @xcite : we start by showing that , up to conjugacy , the @xmath508 hyperelliptic rotations with pairwise distinct odd prime orders can be chosen to commute on the submanifold @xmath513 of @xmath2 corresponding to the subtree @xmath514 .",
    "we consider then the maximal subtree corresponding to a submanifold of @xmath2 on which these hyperelliptic rotations commute up to conjugacy and prove that such subtree is in fact @xmath190 .",
    "then the conclusion follows as in the proof of theorem  [ th : solvable ] , by applying proposition  [ prop : commuting rotations ] .",
    "the first step of the proof is achieved by the following proposition :    [ prop : commuting submanifold ] the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath515 commute , up to conjugacy in @xmath449 , on the submanifold @xmath513 of @xmath2 corresponding to the subtree @xmath514 .",
    "since the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath189 have odd orders , either @xmath514 contains an edge , or it consists of a single vertex .",
    "we shall analyse these two cases .",
    "* case 1 : @xmath513 contains an edge .",
    "*    [ claim : invariant edge ] assume that @xmath514 contains an edge and let @xmath121 denote the corresponding torus . the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath515 commute , up to conjugacy in @xmath449 , on the geometric pieces of @xmath2 adjacent to @xmath121 .",
    "the geometric pieces adjacent to @xmath121 are left invariant by the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath515 , since their orders are odd .",
    "let @xmath516 denote one of the two adjacent geometric pieces : each hyperelliptic rotation acts non - trivially on @xmath516 with odd prime order .",
    "we distinguish two cases according to the geometry of @xmath516 .",
    "* @xmath516 is hyperbolic . * in this case all rotations act as isometries and leave a cusp invariant .",
    "since their order is odd , the rotations must act as translations along horospheres , and thus commute .",
    "note that , even in the case where a rotation has order @xmath0 , its axis can not meet a torus of the jsj - decomposition of @xmath2 for each such torus is separating and can not meet the axis in an odd number of points .",
    "* @xmath516 is seifert fibred . * in this case we can assume that the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath506 preserve the seifert fibration with orientable base",
    ". since their orders are odd and prime , each one preserves the orientation of the fibres and of the base . the conjugacy class of a fiber - preserving rotation of @xmath516 with odd prime order depends only on its combinatorial behaviour , i.e. its translation action along the fibre and the induced permutation on cone points and boundary components of the base . in particular , two geometric rotations with odd prime order having the same combinatorial data are conjugate via a diffeomorphism isotopic to the identity .",
    "since the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath515 have pairwise distinct odd prime orders , an analysis of the different cases described in lemma  [ lem : seifert ] below shows that at most one among these hyperelliptic rotations can induce a non trivial action on the base of the fibration , and thus the remaining ones act by translation along the fibres and induce the idendity on the base . since the translation along the fibres commutes with every fiber - preserving diffeomorphism of @xmath516 , the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath515 commute on @xmath516 .",
    "lemma  [ lem : seifert ] describes the seifert fibred pieces of a manifold admitting a hyperelliptic rotation of odd prime order , as well as the action of the rotation on the pieces .",
    "its proof can be found in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 6 and proof of lemma 7 ) , see also ( * ? ? ?",
    "[ lem : seifert ] let @xmath2 be an irreducible @xmath0-manifold admitting a non trivial jsj - decomposition .",
    "assume that @xmath2 admits a hyperelliptic rotation of prime odd order @xmath8 .",
    "let @xmath516 be a seifert piece of the jsj - decomposition for @xmath2 .",
    "then the base @xmath517 of @xmath516 can be :    1 .   a disc with @xmath6 cone points .",
    "in this case either the rotation freely permutes @xmath8 copies of @xmath516 or leaves @xmath516 invariant and acts by translating along the fibres .",
    "2 .   a disc with @xmath8 cone points . in this case",
    "the rotation leaves @xmath516 invariant and cyclically permutes the singular fibres , while leaving a regular one invariant .",
    "3 .   a disc with @xmath460 cone points . in this case",
    "the rotation leaves @xmath516 and a singular fibre invariant , while cyclically permuting the remaining @xmath8 singular fibres .",
    "an annulus with @xmath518 cone point . in this case",
    "either the rotation freely permutes @xmath8 copies of @xmath516 or leaves @xmath516 invariant and acts by translating along the fibres . 5 .   an annulus with @xmath8 cone points .",
    "in this case the rotation leaves @xmath516 invariant and cyclically permutes the @xmath8 singular fibres .",
    "6 .   a disc with @xmath519 holes and @xmath518 cone point .",
    "in this case the rotation leaves @xmath516 invariant and cyclically permutes all @xmath8 boundary components , while leaving invariant the only singular fibre and a regular one .",
    "7 .   a disc with @xmath12 holes , @xmath520 .",
    "in this case either the rotation freely permutes @xmath8 copies of @xmath516 or leaves @xmath516 invariant . in this latter case",
    "either the rotation acts by translating along the fibres , or @xmath521 and the rotation permutes all the boundary components ( while leaving invariant two fibres ) , or @xmath522 and the rotation permutes @xmath8 boundary components , while leaving invariant the remaining one and a regular fibre .",
    "we conclude that the rotations in @xmath515 can be chosen to commute on the submanifold @xmath513 of @xmath2 corresponding to @xmath514 by using inductively at each edge of @xmath514 the gluing lemma below ( see [ lemma 6]@xcite ) .",
    "we give the proof for the sake of completeness .",
    "[ lem : gluing ] if the rotations preserve a jsj - torus @xmath121 then they commute on the union of the two geometric pieces adjacent to @xmath121 .",
    "let @xmath516 and @xmath523 be the two geometric pieces adjacent to @xmath121 . by claim [ claim : invariant edge ] , after conjugacy in @xmath212 , the rotations in @xmath515 commute on @xmath516 and @xmath523 . since they have pairwise distinct odd prime orders , their restrictions on @xmath516 and @xmath523 generate two cyclic groups of the same finite odd order .",
    "let @xmath524 and @xmath525 be generators of these two cyclic groups . since they have odd order , they both act by translation on @xmath121 . we need the following result about the slope of translation for such periodic transformation of the torus :    [ claim : slope ] let @xmath21 be a periodic diffeomorphism of the product @xmath526 $ ] which is isotopic to the identity and whose restriction to each boundary torus @xmath527 , @xmath528 is a translation with rational slopes @xmath529 and @xmath530 in @xmath531 . then @xmath532 .    by meeks and scott (",

    "now the the following claim shows that the actions of @xmath525 and @xmath524 can be glued on @xmath121 .",
    "[ claim : identification ] the translations @xmath535 and @xmath536 have the same slope in @xmath531 .",

    "* case 2 : @xmath513 is a vertex .",
    "*    [ claim : one vertex ] assume that @xmath514 consists of a single vertex and let @xmath516 denote the corresponding geometric piece .",
    "then the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath515 commute on @xmath516 , up to conjugacy in @xmath449 .",
    "we consider again two cases according to the geometry of @xmath516 .",
    "the case where @xmath516 is seifert fibred follows once more from lemma  [ lem : seifert ] .",
    "we consider now the case where @xmath516 is hyperbolic .    in this case , the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath506 act non trivially on @xmath516 by isometries of odd prime orders .",
    "the restriction @xmath546 of the action of the subgroup @xmath40 that they generate in @xmath449 is finite .",
    "if the action on @xmath516 of the cyclic subgroups generated by two of the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath506 are conjugate in @xmath547 , one can conjugate the actions in @xmath449 to coincide on @xmath516 , since any diffeomorphism in @xmath547 extends to @xmath2 .",
    "then by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 10 ) these actions must coincide on @xmath2 , contradicting the hypothesis that the conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath506 are pairwise distinct in @xmath449 . hence , the cyclic subgroup generated by the @xmath500 hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath506 are pairwise not conjugate in the finite group @xmath548",
    ".    since the dual graph of the jsj - decomposition of @xmath2 is a tree , a boundary torus @xmath549 is separating and bounds a component @xmath550 of @xmath551 .",
    "since , by hypothesis , @xmath514 consists of a single vertex , no boundary component @xmath121 is setwise fixed by the finite group @xmath547 .",
    "this means that there is a hyperelliptic rotation @xmath552 of odd prime order @xmath537 such that the orbit of @xmath550 under @xmath117 is the disjoint union of @xmath537 copies of @xmath550 .",
    "in particular @xmath550 projects homeomorphically onto a knot exterior in the quotient @xmath553 . therefore on each boundary torus @xmath554 , there is a simple closed curve @xmath555 , unique up to isotopy , that bounds a properly embedded incompressible and @xmath556-incompressible seifert surface @xmath557 in the knot exterior @xmath550 .    by pinching the surface @xmath557 onto a disc @xmath558 , in each component @xmath550 of @xmath551",
    ", one defines a degree - one map @xmath559 , where @xmath560 is the rational homology sphere obtained by dehn filling each boundary torus @xmath561 along the curve @xmath555 .    for each hyperelliptic rotation @xmath117 in @xmath506 , of odd prime order @xmath537 ,",
    "the @xmath117-orbit of each component @xmath550 of @xmath551 consists of either one or @xmath537 elements . as a consequence , by @xcite ,",
    "@xmath117 acts equivariantly on the set of isotopy classes of curves @xmath562 .",
    "hence , each @xmath117 extends to periodic diffeomorphism @xmath563 of order @xmath537 on @xmath560 .",
    "moreover , @xmath560 is a @xmath564-homology sphere , since so is @xmath2 and @xmath559 is a degree - one map .",
    "according to smith s theory , if @xmath565 is non - empty on @xmath560 , then @xmath563 is a rotation on @xmath560 . to see that @xmath566 on @xmath560 it suffices to observe that either @xmath567 or @xmath117 is a rotation of some @xmath550 ; in this latter case , @xmath563 must have a fixed point on the disc @xmath558 onto which the surface @xmath557 is pinched . to show that @xmath563 is hyperelliptic it remains to show that the quotient @xmath568 is homeomorphic to @xmath1 .",
    "since @xmath117 acts equivariantly on the components @xmath550 of @xmath551 and on the set of isotopy classes of curves @xmath562 , the quotient @xmath553 is obtained from the compact @xmath0-manifold @xmath569 by gluing knot exteriors ( maybe solid tori ) to its boundary components , in such a way that the boundaries of the seifert surfaces of the knot exteriors are glued to the curves @xmath570 .    in the same way",
    ", the rotation @xmath563 acts equivariantly on the components @xmath571 and on the set of isotopy classes of curves @xmath562 . by construction , these components are solid tori , and either the axis of the rotation is contained in @xmath516 or there exists a unique torus @xmath572 such that the solid torus glued to @xmath121 to obtain @xmath560 contains the axis . in the latter case , by (",
    "2.2 ) , the rotation @xmath563 preserves a meridian disc of this solid torus and its axis is a core of @xmath573 .",
    "it follows that the images in the quotient @xmath568 of the the solid tori glued to @xmath574 are again solid tori .",
    "hence @xmath568 is obtained from @xmath1 by replacing each components of @xmath575 by a solid torus , in such way that boundaries of meridian discs of the solid tori are glued to the curves @xmath576 .",
    "it follows that @xmath568 is again @xmath1 .",
    "so far we have constructed a closed orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath560 with a finite subgroup of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms @xmath577 that contains at least seven conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime orders .",
    "theorem  [ th : main3 ] implies that @xmath560 must be @xmath1 , and thus by the orbifold theorem @xcite @xmath577 is conjugate to a finite subgroup of @xmath578 .",
    "in particular the subgroup @xmath579 generated by the subset @xmath515 of at least @xmath74 hyperelliptic rotations with pairwise distinct odd prime orders must be solvable .",
    "therefore , by proposition  [ prop : commuting 2 ] the induced rotations commute on @xmath560 and , by restriction , the hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath515 commute on @xmath516 .    in the final step of the proof",
    "we extend the commutativity on @xmath513 to the whole manifold @xmath2 .",
    "the proof of this step is analogous to the one given in @xcite , since the proof there was not using the homology assumption .",
    "we give the argument for the sake of completeness .",
    "[ prop : whole commuting ] the @xmath508 hyperelliptic rotations in @xmath515 commute , up to conjugacy in @xmath449 , on @xmath2 .",
    "let @xmath580 be the largest subtree of @xmath190 containing @xmath514 , such that , up to conjugacy in @xmath212 , the rotations in @xmath515 commute on the corresponding invariant submanifold @xmath581 of @xmath2 .",
    "we shall show that @xmath582 . if this is not the case , we can choose an edge contained in @xmath190 corresponding to a boundary torus @xmath121 of @xmath581 .",
    "denote by @xmath550 the submanifold of @xmath2 adjacent to @xmath121 but not containing @xmath581 and by @xmath583 the geometric piece adjacent to @xmath121 .",
    "let @xmath584 be the group of diffeomorphisms of @xmath2 generated by the set of geometric hyperelliptic rotations @xmath509 .",
    "since the rotations in @xmath515 commute on @xmath581 and have pairwise distinct odd prime orders , the restriction of @xmath585 on on @xmath581 is a cyclic group with order the product of the orders of the rotations . since @xmath586 , the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath121 can not be reduced to only one element .",
    "moreover each rotation @xmath587 either fixes @xmath121 or acts freely on the orbit of @xmath121 since its order is prime .",
    "if no rotation in @xmath515 leaves @xmath121 invariant , the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath121 contains as many elements as the product of the orders of the rotations , for they commute on @xmath581 .",
    "in particular , only the identity ( which extends to @xmath119 ) stabilises a torus in the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath121 .",
    "note that all components of @xmath588 are in the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath121 and bound a manifold homeomorphic to @xmath550 .",
    "since the rotation @xmath117 acts freely on the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath550 , @xmath550 is a knot exterior in the quotient @xmath589 .",
    "hence there is a well defined meridian - longitude system on @xmath590 and also on each torus of the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath121 .",
    "this set of meridian - longitude systems is cyclically permuted by each @xmath117 and thus equivariant under the action of @xmath585 .",
    "let @xmath591 be the quotient of @xmath581 by the induced cyclic action of @xmath585 on @xmath581 .",
    "then there is a unique boundary component @xmath592 which is the image of the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath121 .",
    "we can glue a copy of the knot exterior @xmath550 to @xmath591 along @xmath593 by identifying the image of the meridian - longitude system on @xmath594 with the projection on @xmath593 of the equivariant meridian - longitude systems on the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath121 .",
    "denote by @xmath60 the resulting manifold . for all @xmath595 , consider the cyclic ( possibly branched ) cover of @xmath60 of order @xmath596 which is induced by the cover @xmath597 .",
    "this makes sense because @xmath598 .",
    "call @xmath599 the total space of such covering . by construction",
    "it follows that @xmath599 is the quotient @xmath600 .",
    "this implies that the @xmath117 s commute on @xmath601 contradicting the maximality of @xmath580 .",
    "we can thus assume that some rotations fix @xmath121 and some do not .",
    "since all rotations commute on @xmath581 and have pairwise distinct odd prime orders , we see that the orbit of @xmath121 consists of as many elements as the product of the orders of the rotations which do not fix @xmath121 and each element of the orbit is fixed by the rotations which leave @xmath121 invariant . the rotations which fix @xmath121 commute on the orbit of @xmath602 according to claim  [ claim : invariant edge ] and lemma [ lem : gluing ] , and form a cyclic group generated by , say , @xmath199 .",
    "the argument for the previous case shows that the rotations acting freely on the orbit of @xmath121 commute on the orbit of @xmath550 and thus on the orbit of @xmath602 , and form again a cyclic group generated by , say , @xmath603 . to reach a contradiction to the maximality of @xmath581",
    ", we shall show that @xmath199 , after perhaps some conjugacy , commutes with @xmath603 on the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath602 , in other words that @xmath199 and @xmath604 coincide on @xmath605 .",
    "since @xmath603 acts freely and transitively on the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath602 there is a natural and well - defined way to identify each element of the orbit @xmath605 to @xmath602 itself .",
    "note that this is easily seen to be the case if @xmath602 is hyperbolic : this follows from claim  [ claim : invariant edge ] and claim  [ claim : slope ] .",
    "we now consider the case when @xmath602 is seifert fibred .",
    "[ claim : consistent action ] assume that @xmath602 is seifert fibred and that the restriction of @xmath199 induces a non - trivial action on the base of @xmath602 .",
    "then @xmath199 induces a non - trivial action on the base of each component of the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath602 .",
    "moreover , up to conjugacy on @xmath606 by diffeomorphisms which are the identity on @xmath607 and extend to @xmath2 , we can assume that the restrictions of @xmath199 to these components induce the same permutation of their boundary components and the same action on their bases .    by hypothesis @xmath199 and @xmath604 coincide on @xmath588 .",
    "the action of @xmath199 on the base of @xmath602 is non - trivial if and only if its restriction to the boundary circle of the base corresponding to the fibres of the torus @xmath121 is non - trivial .",
    "therefore the action of @xmath199 is non - trivial on the base of each component of @xmath605 .    by lemma  [ lem : seifert ] and taking into account the fact that @xmath602 is a geometric piece in the jsj - decomposition of the knot exterior @xmath550 , the only situation in which the action of @xmath199 on the base of @xmath602 is non - trivial",
    "is when the base of @xmath602 consists of a disc with @xmath8 holes , where @xmath8 is the order of one of the rotations that generate @xmath199 , the only one whose action is non trivial on the base of the fibration .",
    "moreover , the restriction of @xmath199 to the elements of @xmath605 cyclically permutes their boundary components which are not adjacent to @xmath581 . up to performing dehn twists , along vertical tori inside the components of @xmath608 , which permute the boundary components",
    ", we can assume that the restriction of @xmath199 induces the same cyclic permutations on the boundary components of each element of the orbit @xmath605 .",
    "we only need to check that dehn twists permuting two boundary components extend to the whole manifold @xmath2 .",
    "this follows from the fact that the manifolds adjacent to these components are all homeomorphic and that dehn twist act trivially on the homology of the boundary .",
    "since the actions of the restrictions of @xmath199 on the bases of the elements of @xmath605 are combinatorially equivalent , after perhaps a further conjugacy by an isotopy , the different restrictions can be chosen to coincide on the bases .    by claim  [ claim : invariant edge ] and",
    "claim  [ claim : consistent action ] we can now deduce that the restrictions of @xmath199 and @xmath604 to the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath602 commute , up to conjugacy of @xmath199 which is the identity on the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath121 . since @xmath199 and @xmath604 coincide on this @xmath585-orbit of @xmath121 , we can conclude that they coincide on the @xmath585-orbit of @xmath602 .",
    "this finishes the proof of proposition  [ prop : whole commuting ] .    since there are at least four hyperelliptic rotations with paiwise distinct odd prime orders in @xmath515 , proposition  [ prop : finitereduction ] is consequence of proposition [ prop : whole commuting ] and proposition  [ prop : commuting rotations ] , like in the solvable case , or by applying theorem  [ th : solvable ] .",
    "as we have seen , the strategy to prove that an irreducible manifold @xmath2 with non - trivial jsj - decomposition can not admit more than six conjugacy classes of subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime order inside @xmath212 consists in modifying by conjugacy any given set of hyperelliptic rotations so that the new hyperelliptic rotations commute pairwise .",
    "note that this strategy can not be carried out in genral if the orders are not pairwise coprime ( see , for instance , ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 4.1 ) where the case of two hyperelliptic rotations of the same odd prime order , generating non conjugate subgroups , is considered ) .",
    "similarly , for hyperelliptic rotations of arbitrary orders @xmath465 lack of commutativity might arise on the seifert fibred pieces of the decomposition , as it does for the seifert fibred manifolds constructed in proposition  [ prop : circle bundles ] .",
    "we proved theorem  [ th : main3 ] for hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime order . in theorem",
    "[ th : main4 ] the assumption that the hyperelliptic rotations have orders that are not powers of @xmath6 , ensures that each hyperelliptic rotation has a non trivial power whose order is an odd prime .",
    "the proof of theorem  [ th : main4 ] reduces to that of theorem  [ th : main3 ] once we observe that powers of hyperelliptic rotations enjoy the same properties as hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime order provided that the powers have themselves odd prime order . as a consequence",
    ", the hyperelliptic rotations of odd prime order can be replaced by powers of odd prime order of hyperelliptic rotations in the proof .",
    "th : main4 let @xmath2 be a closed orientable connected @xmath0-manifold which is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath5 be a finite subgroup of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of @xmath2 .",
    "then @xmath5 contains at most six conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of order not a power of two .    for each hyperelliptic rotation @xmath43 in @xmath5",
    "let @xmath8 be an odd prime dividing its order and @xmath45 a non trivial power of @xmath43 of order @xmath8 .",
    "the key points to reduce the proof of theorem  [ th : main4 ] to that of theorem  [ th : main3 ] are the following :    1 .",
    "as explained in subsection  [ subsec : arbitrary - order ] , if @xmath43 is a hyperelliptic rotation in @xmath5 and @xmath8 is an odd prime dividing the order of @xmath43 , then a sylow @xmath8-subgroup of @xmath5 has the same algebraic properties as a sylow @xmath8-subgroup where @xmath8 is hyperelliptic .",
    "these properties are all that is needed in the proof of theorem  [ th : main3 ] .",
    "if @xmath43 itself has order @xmath8 and the sylow @xmath8-subgroup has rank @xmath6 , then exactly two cyclic groups generated by a rotation of order @xmath8 are contained in that sylow @xmath8-subgroup . in the general case , that is , when @xmath45 belongs to the sylow @xmath8-subgroup , this is not true anymore but we have at most two cyclic groups of order @xmath8 generated by elements with non - empty fixed - point sets , according to lemma  [ lem:2hyprot ] .",
    "we remark that if two hyperelliptic rotations have a common non - trivial power , then their fixed - point sets coincide and , by lemma  [ lem : commuting powers suffice ] , they generate the same cyclic group .",
    "this implies also that if two non - trivial powers of two hyperelliptic rotations are conjugate , then so are the subgroups generated by the two rotations .",
    "as noted in remark  [ rem : otherwise ] we know that proposition  [ prop : quotient action ] holds also in the general case . in the general case",
    "the subgroup @xmath164 can be replaced by the maximal normal solvable subgroup of odd order coprime with any prime that divides the order of a hyperelliptic rotation and @xmath165 can be replaced by the maximal normal solvable subgroup of order coprime with any odd prime that divides the order of a hyperelliptic rotation .",
    "4 .   theorem  [ th : solvable ] and proposition  [ prop : commuting rotations ] ensure that there are at most three commuting cyclic subgroups of hyperelliptic rotations of order not a power of @xmath6 , also in this setting .",
    "thus we can exploit the strategy to cover the group with solvable groups in the general case , too , and the results of section  [ sec : nonselfsym ] hold .",
    "5 .   in section",
    "[ sec : thm3 ] the proof is based essentially on the algebraic structure of the sylow @xmath8-subgroups when @xmath8 is hyperelliptic , so the arguments apply to cover the case of hyperelliptic rotations of order not a power of @xmath6 .",
    "it is worth pointing out that items 1 . and 2 .",
    "above imply that if @xmath5 is a finite group of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms acting on a manifold @xmath36 then , for any odd prime @xmath8 , the cyclic subgroups generated by hyperelliptic rotations whose orders are divisible by @xmath8 belong to at most two different conjugacy classes .",
    "the proofs of theorems  [ th : main3 ] and [ th : main4 ] show that there are constraints on the structure of a finite group containing at least four conjugacy classes of hyperelliptic rotations with orders not powers of @xmath6 .",
    "we have :    [ prop : structure ] let @xmath5 be a finite group of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed connected @xmath0-manifold @xmath36 .",
    "assume that @xmath5 contains at least four conjugacy classes of hyperelliptic rotations whose orders are not powers of @xmath6 .",
    "then , there is a solvable normal subgroup @xmath60 of @xmath5 such that :    * the layer @xmath177 has at most two components , which implies that so does @xmath5 ; * if the layer @xmath177 has two components , then @xmath446 .    moreover ,",
    "if @xmath129 is not a subgroup of @xmath229 , then any odd prime dividing the order of a hyperelliptic rotation does not divide the order of @xmath60 .",
    "the case of hyperelliptic rotations of order a power of @xmath6 is considered in @xcite and @xcite .",
    "we remark that , if a manifold admits a hyperelliptic rotation of order @xmath447 , then the manifold is a @xmath34-homology sphere ( see  @xcite ) . combining the results in @xcite and @xcite",
    "we obtain the following result .",
    "[ th : powers of two ] let @xmath2 be a closed orientable connected @xmath0-manifold which is not homeomorphic to @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath5 be a finite group of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of @xmath2 .",
    "then @xmath5 contains at most nine conjugacy classes of cyclic subgroups generated by a hyperelliptic rotation of order a power of @xmath6 and at most two of these conjugacy classes contain cyclic subgroups of order strictly greater than @xmath6 .",
    "now corollary  [ cor:4bis ] for hyperbolic manifold is a consequence of theorems  [ th : main4 ] and [ th : powers of two ] .",
    "in this short section we shall discuss finite groups of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms generated by hyperelliptic rotations and acting on reducible manifolds .",
    "we shall see that theorem  [ th : main3 ] is trivially fulfilled in this setting .",
    "the proof we give in the general case works also for the reducible one but here the situation is much simpler and is described by the following proposition .",
    "[ pro : reducible ] let @xmath2 be a reducible manifold and let @xmath29 be a finite group generated by at least two hyperelliptic rotations with distinct orders .",
    "in this case @xmath5 is isomorphic to a finite subgroup of @xmath448 , and thus , up to conjugacy , @xmath5 contains at most three cyclic groups generated by hyperelliptic rotations .",
    "since @xmath5 is a finite group , we can assume that it acts by isometries with respect to some riemannian metric on @xmath2 .",
    "moreover , by the equivariant sphere theorem , we can assume that there is a prime decomposition of @xmath2 into irreducible components which is @xmath5-equivariant .",
    "note that each hyperelliptic rotation must fix setwise each sphere of the decomposition since the space of orbits is @xmath1 , hence so must @xmath5 .",
    "since @xmath5 acts by isometries , its action is determined by the action on any sphere of the decomposition .",
    "it follows that @xmath5 is conjugate to a finite subgroup of @xmath448 , that is cyclic , dihedral or a spherical triangular group .",
    "in this section we will show that every finite group @xmath5 admits a faithful action by orientation preserving diffeomorphisms on some rational homology sphere so that some elements of @xmath5 have non - empty fixed - point sets .",
    "cooper and long s construction of @xmath5-actions on rational homolgy spheres in @xcite consists in starting with a @xmath5-action on some @xmath0-manifold and then modifying the original manifold , notably by dehn surgery , so that the new manifold inherits a @xmath5-action but has  smaller \" rational homology .",
    "since their construction does not require that the @xmath5-action is free , it can be used to prove the existence of non - free @xmath5-actions .",
    "we will thus start by exhibiting non - free @xmath5-actions on some @xmath0-manifold before pointing out what need to be taken into account in this setting in order for cooper and long s construction to work .",
    "[ claim : non - free action ] let @xmath5 be a finite non - cyclic group .",
    "there is a closed , connected , orientable @xmath0-manifold @xmath2 on which @xmath5 acts faitfully , by orientation preserving diffeomorphisms so that there are @xmath609 with the property that @xmath78 .",
    "consider the free group of rank @xmath12 that we wish to see as the fundamental group of a @xmath616-punctured @xmath6-sphere : each generator @xmath617 corresponds to a loop around a puncture of the sphere so that a loop around the @xmath618st puncture corresponds to the element @xmath619 .",
    "build an orbifold @xmath620 by compactifying the punctured - sphere with cone points so that the @xmath364th puncture becomes a cone point of order @xmath621 .",
    "the resulting orbifold has ( orbifold ) fundamental group with the following presentation : @xmath622 clearly this group surjects onto @xmath5 .",
    "such surjection gives rise to an orbifold covering @xmath623 , where @xmath343 is an orientable surface on which @xmath5 acts in such a way that each element @xmath613 has non - empty fixed - point set .",
    "one can consider the @xmath0-manifold @xmath624 : the action of @xmath5 on @xmath343 extends to a product action of @xmath5 on @xmath624 which is trivial on the @xmath495 factor .    to be able to repeat cooper and long s construction",
    "it is now easy to observe that it is always possible to choose @xmath5-equivariant families of simple closed curves in @xmath2 so that they miss the fixed - point sets of elements of @xmath5 and either their homology classes generate @xmath625 ( so that the hypothesis of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 2.3 ) are fulfilled when we choose @xmath626 to be the exterior of such families ) or the family is the @xmath5-orbit of a representative of some prescribed homology class ( as in the proof of ( * ? ?",
    "* proposition 2.5 ) ) .",
    "m. boileau , l. paoluzzi and b. zimmermann , _ a characterisation of @xmath627 among homology spheres _ , the zieschang gedenkschrift .",
    "* 14 * , geom .",
    "publ . , coventry , ( 2008 ) , 83 - 103 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we show that a hyperbolic @xmath0-manifold can be the cyclic branched cover of at most fifteen knots in @xmath1 . </S>",
    "<S> this is a consequence of a general result about finite groups of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms acting on @xmath0-manifolds . a similar </S>",
    "<S> , although weaker , result holds for arbitrary irreducible @xmath0-manifolds : an irreducible @xmath0-manifold can be the cyclic branched cover of odd prime order of at most six knots in @xmath1 .    _ </S>",
    "<S> ams classification : _ </S>",
    "<S> primary 57s17 ; secondary 57m40 ; 57m60 ; 57m12 ; 57m25 ; 57m50 .    </S>",
    "<S> _ keywords : _ finite group actions , homology spheres , geometric structures in dimension @xmath0 , cyclic branched covers of knots . </S>"
  ]
}
